MRE11, MRE11 homolog, double strand break repair nuclease, functions as part of a complex involved in DNA double strand break repair, and plays a role in regulation of telomerase activity (PMID:     22914783). MRE11 aberrations are associated with breast and ovarian cancer (PMID: 25447316, PMID: 26436112).

FOLR1, folate receptor 1, encodes folate receptor-alpha, which is a membrane-tethered receptor involved in transport of folate into the cell (PMID: 16453285). FOLR1 is over expressed in several tumor types (PMID: 16453285).

EIF1AX, eukaryotic translation initiation factor 1A X-linked, encodes a protein that stimulates 43S ternary complex formation, which initiates protein translation (PMID: 24499181), and is essential for cell proliferation (PMID: 30420357). EIF1AX mutations have been identified in uveal melanoma (PMID: 23793026, PMID: 27123562), low-grade serous ovarian carcinoma (PMID: 28646021), and thyroid neoplasms (PMID: 26911375).
ACP3, acid phosphatase 3, prostate, is an androgen-regulated and non-specific acid phosphatase (UniProt.org). A fusion with ACPP and PIK3CB has been observed in prostate cancer (PMID: 26000489).

ELOC, elongin C, is a component of RNA polymerase II elongation factor complex that promotes mRNA elongation (PMID: 7660129), and also a subunit of the VHL tumor suppressor complex that activates HIF1alpha ubiquitination (PMID: 10973499). ELOC mutations have been identified in clear-cell renal cell carcinoma (PMID: 23797736), ELOC amplification and overexpression have been identified in prostate cancer (PMID: 12004003).

ASPH, aspartyl/asparaginyl beta-hydroxylase, hydroxylates certain residues within EGF-domain containing proteins, including Notch and Jagged to promote cell migration (PMID: 28985022). Altered ASPH expression has been observed in hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 24954865), cholangiocarcinoma (PMID: 26954680), and luminal B breast cancer (PMID: 28985022).

IL2RA, interleukin 2 receptor subunit alpha, also known as CD25, acts as low-affinity receptor for IL2 and forms the high-affinity IL2 receptor in conjunction with IL2RB and ILR2G, and plays a role in activation and proliferation of immune cells (PMID: 23352221, PMID: 28556984). IL2RA expression is associated with several hematological tumor types, including adult T-cell leukemia and hairy cell leukemia (PMID: 28556984).

TAF1, TATA-box binding protein associated factor 1, is a major component of the transcription factor II D (TFIID) complex that has histone acetyltransferase and kinase activities (PMID: 8980232, PMID: 8625415), regulates expression of genes involved in cell cycle and apoptosis (PMID: 10716982). TAF1 mutations have been identified in uterine serous carcinoma (PMID: 23359684), gastric, colorectal (PMID: 27571988), and clear cell endometrial cancer (PMID: 28485815).

PPFIBP2, liprin-beta-2, is a member of the transmembrane protein-tyrosine phosphatase interacting protein family, which are scaffolding proteins involved in the development of neuronal synapses (PMID: 21462929). PPFIBP2 fusions with BRAF have been identified in thyroid cancer (PMID: 28351223) and melanoma (PMID: 30254212).

PAX8, paired-box 8, is a transcription factor, which is involved in the differentiation of multiple cell types including thyroid, kidney, and neural tube (PMID: 23868062). PAX8 expression has been associated with several cancer types including thyroid, renal, ovarian, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, while PAX8 translocations have been identified in thyroid cancers (PMID: 23425942).

ERF, ETS2 repressor factor, encodes for a member of the ETS transcription factor family, which acts as a transcriptional repressor by binding to promoters that have an Ets binding site (PMID: 7588608). ERF mutations have been identified in prostate cancer (PMID: 28515055).

ZBTB7A, zinc finger and BTB domain containing 7A, is a member of the POK family transcription repressors that regulates cell cycle, apoptosis, and hematopoietic cell lineage decision (PMID: 16204018, PMID: 23396304). ZBTB7A amplification and overexpression have been identified in breast (PMID: 20394500), ovarian (PMID: 21176152), prostate (PMID: 21251909), non-small cell lung cancer (PMID: 17907153), and diffuse large B cell lymphoma (PMID: 16204018), and decreased Zbtb7a expression has been identified in oral squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 25439053).

TET2, methylcytosine dioxygenase TET2, is a member of the ten-eleven-translocation family of genes that plays a role in DNA methylation and is involved in hematopoesis (PMID: 26099018, PMID: 25510268, PMID: 27848178). TET2 has been identified as a tumor suppressor in hematological malignancies, and mutations in TET2 are common in hematological cancers including myelodysplastic syndrome, chronic myelomoncytic leukemia, and atypical CML (PMID: 26099018, PMID: 22240200, PMID: 30138727) and epigenetic dysregulation has been observed in glioblastoma (PMID: 29899831).

PRLR, prolactin receptor, is a member of the type 1 cytokine receptor superfamily that binds the hormone, prolactin, to activate Jak2/Stat5, MAPK, and PI3K pathways for control of lactation (PMID: 28377489, PMID: 27107001). Overexpression of PRLR has been observed in multiple subtypes of breast cancer (PMID: 28377489).

CCNG2, cyclin G2, regulates cell cycle arrest in response to ligand signaling, DNA damage, and other cellular stress signals (PMID: 27753529). CCNG2 is a putative tumor suppressor gene that has decreased expression in several aggressive cancer types (PMID: 29720957, PMID: 30115848).

INO80C, INO80 complex subunit C, is a component of the ATP-dependent  chromatin remodeling INO80 complex (PMID: 21303910). Mutations or loss of INO80 have been reported to affect  genome stability and DNA repair pathways (PMID: 23207916; PMID: 22749148).

AGBL4, ATP/GTP binding protein like 4, is a cytosolic carboxypeptidase that catalyzes the removal of glutamate residues from polyglutamyl side chains of proteins (PMID: 21074048). A fusion of AGBL4 with NTRK2 has been observed in pediatric glioma (PMID: 24705251).

SMO, smoothened, frizzled class receptor, is a G-protein coupled receptor and member of the Hedgehog signaling pathway, which is involved in cell fate, proliferation, and survival (PMID: 16881963). SMO gain-of-function mutations are associated with basal cell carcinoma (PMID: 25085664) and several missense mutations are associated with resistance to Hedgehog pathway inhibitors (PMID: 29175550, PMID: 25306392).

FMO4, flavin containing monooxygenase 4, is a dimethylaniline monooxygenase (N-oxide-forming) family member, which are highly expressed in liver and metabolize drugs and other foreign compounds (PMID: 19307449). Fmo4 expression was reported in glioblastoma patients with a favorable outcome to a combination of Avastin (bevacizumab) and Lomustine (PMID: 26762204).

AFAP1, actin filament associated protein 1, binds actin and regulates actin filament organization, plays a role in SRC activation, and may function as an adaptor protein for signaling molecules (PMID: 11607843, PMID: 21236256, PMID: 25043309). AFAP1 over expression has been demonstrated in prostate cancer (PMID: 17885682), and a fusion between AFAP1 and NTRK2 has been demonstrated in low-grade glioma (PMID: 25204415).

TRIM33, tripartite motif containing 33, has multiple functions including E3-ubiquitin ligase and transcriptional coregulatory activity, and plays a role in DNA repair, cell-cycle, and hematopoeisis (PMID: 25639486, PMID: 26282171). TRIM33 has tumor suppressor activity, and fusions and decreased expression have been identified in several tumor types (PMID: 25639486, PMID: 26282171).

COP1, constitutive photomorphogenesis protein 1, is a COP-DET-FUS family member and an ubiquitously expressed E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase that mediates substrate ubiquitinylation, and functions both as a tumor suppressor and an oncogene (PMID: 22673153, PMID: 21572435, PMID: 21403399). A fusion of COP1 with NTRK1 has been observed in large-cell neuroendocrine carcinoma (Cancer Res 2014;74(19 Suppl):Abstract nr 1531).

STARD3NL, STARD3 N-terminal like, is a tether protein that bridges the the endoplasmic reticulum with late endosomes through VAPA and VAPB proteins (PMID: 24105263, PMID: 27068960). A STARD3NL-RET fusion has been identified in lung adenocarcinoma (PMID: 29284707).

ARNT, aryl hydrocarbon receptor nuclear translocator, also known as HIF1-beta binds, is a common binding partner for Hif1a and Ahr (PMID: 24849811). ARNT fusions with ETV6 are observed in leukemia and interfere with native Arnt protein function (PMID: 24469860).

CDKN2B (p27), cyclin-dependent kinase 4 inhibitor B, regulates G1-S phase cell cycle arrest via specific inhibition of CDK4 and CDK6 kinases to function as a tumor suppressor (PMID: 27030077). CDKN2B deletions have been identified in liposarcomas (PMID: 21910158) and renal cell carcinomas (PMID: 23898052).
LYSMD3, LysM domain containing 3, is a type II membrane glycoprotein (PMID: 29496999) that may be involved in central nervous system development (PMID: 19471318).

INPP4A, inositol polyphosphate-4-phosphatase type I A, encodes a lipid phosphatase that dephosphorylates phosphatidylinositol-3,4-bisphosphate (PtdIns(3,4)P2) PIP2 into phosphatidylinositol-3,4,5-trisphosphate (PIP3), potentially resulting in PI3K pathway signaling (PMID: 26022180). Decreased expression of INPP4A has been identified in several tumor types, including breast, prostate, and ovarian cancer, melanoma, and leukemia (PMID: 26022180).

POLB, DNA polymerase beta, is the major DNA polymerase involved in DNA base excision repair (BER) and plays a role in mitochondrial function and DNA integrity (PMID: 29129598). POLB is frequently mutated in colorectal cancer (PMID: 22577134) and missense mutations have been reported in gastric cancer (PMID: 25561897).

RELA, RELA proto-oncogene, NF-kB subunit, is a component of the NF-kappa-B complex that is involved in transcription regulation in diverse biological events including inflammation, development, and growth (PMID: 16724054). Overexpression of Rela has been identified in ovarian and adrenal gland cancers (PMID: 29673141), and RELA-fusions have been associated with ependymomas (PMID: 29258295).

H3C11, H3 clustered histone 11, encodes a member of the canonical histone 3 family that may play a role in nucleosome assembly, and DNA replication and repair (PMID: 21263457). Mutations in H3C11 have been identified in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 25484917).

ATP7B, ATPase copper transporting beta, is a transmembrane P-type heavy metal transporting ATPase that moves copper across cell membranes (PMID: 29970670, PMID: 29394468). Expression of ATP7B has been correlated to resistance to platinum-based therapies in multiple tumor types (PMID: 29394468), including non-small cell lung cancer (PMID: 30310510).

EIF3E, eukaryotic translation initiation factor 3 subunit E, is part of the translation intitiation complex (PMID: 25450521). EIF3E fusions with RSPO2 have been observed in colorectal cancer (PMID: 22895193).

PRCC, papillary renal cell carcinoma (translocation-associated), does not have a known biological function, however, is thought to be associated with pre-mRNA splicing (PMID: 19422821). PRCC fusions with TFE3 have been identified in papillary renal cell carcinomas (PMID: 8986805).

ELF4, ETS-related transcription factor Elf-4, is a member of the E26 transformation-specific (ETS) transcription factor family and plays a role in regulating gene transcription, immune system development, and cellular homoeostasis (PMID: 27932483). Elf4 mutations and overexpression have been observed in a variety of tumor types (PMID: 26921333, PMID: 17213815) and a fusion with Erg in AML (PMID: 16303180) and BCORL1 in liver cancer (PMID: 21499249) have been reported.

CNTNAP2, contactin associated protein-like 2, is a member of the neurexin family and functions as a nueral adhesion molecule and plays a role in nervous system development (PMID: 27621318). Decreased expression of CNTNAP2 has been observed in laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 30267217) and promoter hypermethylation has been identified in pancreatic cancer (PMID: 18535405).

FOXO3, forkhead box O3, encodes for a protein belonging to the Forkhead box O family of transcription factors, which plays a role in multiple cellular functions such as cell proliferation, apoptosis, autophagy, and metabolism (PMID: 24864265). Decreased expression of FOXO3 has been associated with worse prognosis in several tumor types including neuroblastoma, gastric, hepatocarcinoma, renal cell carcinoma, and breast cancer (PMID: 25678856).

SALL2, Sal-like protein 2, is a member of the spalt-like (SALL) transcription factor family that regulates a number of gene targets, including TP53, CDKN1A, and MYC and may play a role as a tumor suppressor or oncogene, depending on context (PMID: 28430874, PMID: 27957650). Altered Sall2 expression has been observed in several tumor types, including serous ovarian carcinoma and glioblastoma (PMID: 27957650), and a fusion with Braf has been reported in NSCLC (PMID: 29883838).

EPOR, erythropoietin receptor, is a plasma membrane receptor which dimerizes and regulates erythropoiesis through activation of JAK/STAT, MAPK, and PI3K/AKT signaling pathways (PMID: 25887776). EPOR is overexpressed in a variety of cancer cell types including renal cancer, head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, cervical cancer, glioma (PMID: 25887776), breast (PMID: 28418910), and gastric (PMID: 27086036).

SEPTIN9, septin 9, is a member of the septin family of GTP-binding proteins and localizes to the terminal ends of septin filaments (PMID: 28338090, PMID: 21740328). SEPT9 expresses multiple isoforms and while amplification has been associated with various neoplasms including breast cancer (PMID: 21831286), some isoforms may have a tumor suppressive function (PMID: 28338090).

MLLT3, myeloid/lymphoid or mixed-lineage leukemia; translocated to, 3, is also referred to as AF9 and is a component of the super elongation complex that is involved in hematopoietic cell fate regulation (PMID: 18371451). MLLT3 gene rearrangements are frequently found in leukemia (PMID: 19262598).

TGFA, protransforming growth factor alpha, is a ligand for the EGFR receptor that plays a role in cell proliferation, differentiation, angiogenesis (PMID: 26984929) and may modulate the tumor microenvironment and regulate epithelial-mesenchymal transition (PMID: 30392905). TGFA singaling through EGFR has been implicated in promoting tumorgenesis in a number of tumor types, including TNBC (PMID: 30034618), colorectal cancer (PMID: 30010111), and ovarian cancer (PMID: 28166193).

TACC3, transforming, acidic coiled-coil containing protein 3, interacts with centrosomes and microtubules as well as several other factors to regulate cell division, differentiation, and migration (PMID: 23624299). Dysregulation of TACC3 is associated with several tumor types, and FGFR3-TACC3 fusions have been demonstrated in glioblastoma and cervical cancer (PMID: 23624299, PMID: 26425723).

WRN, Werner syndrome RecQ helicase-like, possesses both DNA helicase and exonuclease activities, thus plays important roles in maintaining genomic stability (PMID: 27902925). Werner syndrome patients with inactivating WRN mutations are prone to cancer (PMID: 16723399), inactivation of WRN is found in multiple cancers (PMID: 25620975), and microsatellite unstable cancers have a dependency on active WRN, suggesting it to be a therapeutic target (PMID: 30971823).

ATM, ATM serine/threonine kinase, is a member of the serine-threonine kinase family and coordinates cellular responses to DNA damage through activation of distinct DNA repair and signaling pathways (PMID: 22079189). ATM germline mutations are associated with ataxia telangiectasia (PMID: 27283171) and ATM somatic mutations are associated with endometrial, colon, pancreatic, breast cancers (PMID: 27283171, PMID: 27413114) and urothelial cancer (PMID: 29682192).

ARID1A, AT rich interactive domain 1A (SWI1-like), is a member of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex and is involved in cell-cycle activation (PMID: 29136504). ARID1A has been reported to influence PI3K/AKT pathways (PMID: 24618703), and loss of function is commonly found in gastric, colorectal (PMID: 28937020), and bladder cancers (PMID: 28583311), while in liver cancer, Arida1a has a context dependent role (PMID: 29136504).

CD5, T-cell surface glycoprotein CD5, is a T-cell activation marker, negative regulator of T-cell receptor signaling, and a putative checkpoint inhibitor (PMID: 30581443). Expression of CD5 has been correlated with poor prognosis in diffuse large B cell lymphoma (PMID: 30519638, PMID: 30019388).

MYD88, myeloid differentiation primary response protein, is an adapter protein involved in Toll-like receptor and IL-1 signaling in the immune response, cytokine secretion, and inflammatory response (PMID: 19506249, PMID: 30086464). MYD88 mutations are frequently identified in hematological malignancies (PMID: 25132836, PMID: 29703722), including B-cell non-hodgkin lymphomas (PMID: 30203262).

FAM133B, family with sequence similarity 133 member B, is a protein coding gene with uncharacterized function (PMID: 23637631). FAM133B fusion has been identified in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (PMID: 23637631).

CARS1, cysteinyl-tRNA synthetase 1, is an enzyme that catalyzes the attachment of cysteine to its corresponding transfer RNA (PMID: 8468064). CARS1 has been identified as a fusion partner with ALK in inflammatory myofibroblastic tumors (PMID: 12112524).

AKT1, protein kinase B alpha, or PKBa, is one of three closely related serine/threonine-protein kinases. This gene is a putative oncogene encoding a protein belonging to a subfamily of serine/threonine kinases containing SH2-like (Src homology 2-like) domains, which is involved in signaling pathways. The gene serves as an oncogene in the tumorigenesis of cancer cells For example, its overexpression contributes to the malignant phenotype of a subset of human ductal pancreatic cancers. The encoded protein is a general protein kinase capable of phophorylating several known proteins, and has also been implicated in insulin signaling. [provided by RefSeq, Nov 2019].

AKT2, RAC-beta serine/threonine-protein kinase, is highly expressed in muscle and adipocytes and contributes to insulin-mediated regulation of glucose homeostasis (PMID: 21620960). In addition AKT2 regulates a number of cell functions, including proliferation, survival, growth, angiogenesis, and metabolism through PI3K signaling (PMID: 28557977).
ABL2,ABLL,ARG

ASXL1, additional sex combs like 1, transcriptional regulator, is involved in epigenetic regulation of gene expression and forms complexes with several proteins to regulate transcription (PMID: 23736028). Mutant ASXL1 protein perturbs hematopoiesis and promotes myeloid transformation by altering histone modifications in both a dominant-negative and gain-of-function manners (PMID: 30927018).

FBXW7, F-box/WD repeat-containing protein 7, is part of the Skp1-Cdc53/Cullin-F-box-protein complex (SCF/β-TrCP), and has three isoforms, FBXW7α, FBXW7β, and FBXW7γ (PMID: 30086763). FBXW7 plays a role in the degradation of proteins involved in cell division and cell growth (PMID: 17909001, PMID: 22673505).

WT1, WT1 transcription factor, that encodes a transcription factor responsible for targeting genes related to cell development, metabolism, and survival (PMID: 17361230). During the cell cycle WT1 governs transcription of pro-survival proteins such as VEGF and BCL2 (PMID: 32152317).

IGF1R, insulin-like growth factor 1 receptor, is a receptor tyrosine kinase which binds IGF1 and enhances its tyrosine kinase activity. IFG1R activates MAPK, PI3K/AKT, and JAK/STAT pathways, promoting cell proliferation, differentiation and decreased apoptosis (PMID: 22520978; PMID: 30338346).

CDH1, cadherin 1, type 1, encodes E-Cadherin and is a tumor suppressor (PMID: 30562755) involved in epithelial cell-cell adhesion, cell signaling, differentiation, and polarity (PMID: 18726070, PMID: 26674224). CDH1 germline mutations are associated with hereditary diffuse gastric cancer (PMID: 30562755) and somatic mutations are found in gastric, breast, colon, and NSCLC cancers (PMID: 27283171, PMID: 25184143).

PIK3C2B, phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate 3-kinase catalytic subunit type 2 beta, is a class II PI3K, which functions to catalyze production of PtdIns3P and plays a role in cell migration and proliferation (PMID: 25233418, PMID: 23320105, PMID: 22507127). PIK3C2B mutations have been identified in non-small cell lung cancer (PMID: 22510280), and PIK3C2B overexpression has been demonstrated in several tumor types, including neuroblastoma (PMID: 25622909), and breast cancer (PMID: 26934321).

TANK, TRAF family member associated NFKB activator, interacts with TRAF proteins and other protein binding partners, and plays a role in regulation of NF-KappaB signaling (PMID: 25861989, PMID: 23139637, PMID: 20484576). TANK has been identified in a fusion with BRAF in thyroid papillary carcinoma (PMID: 26314551).

SDC4, syndecan 4, is a heparan sulfate proteoglycan that plays a role in intracellular signaling, including cell adhesion and cell-matrix interactions (PMID: 23844358). SDC4 expression has been associated with breast cancer and an SDC4 fusion with ROS1 was identified in NSCLC (PMID: 25361632, PMID: 22919003).

IGH, immunoglobulin heavy locus, encodes the protein responsible for synthesizing the various heavy chains of antibodies, the necessary entities of the adaptive immune system (PMID: 23541343). IGH rearrangements are observed in lymphoblastic leukemia, multiple myeloma, and lymphoma (PMID: 10361104, PMID: 23541343, PMID: 18000389).

H3C15, H3 clustered histone 15, encodes a member of the histone H3 family of proteins that may play a role in nucleosome assembly during DNA replication (PMID: 30165676). Overexpression of H3C15 has been demonstrated in a breast cancer cell line (PMID: 24870930).

KAT6A, lysine acetyltransferase 6A, encodes for a histone acetyltransferase and plays a role as a transcriptional co-activator of DNA-binding transcription factors, especially in the context of hematopoiesis (PMID: 23347099). KAT6A fusions with EP300, NCOA2, and CREBBP have been identified in acute myeloid leukemia (PMID: 16626284).

EZH1, enhancer of zeste 1 polycomb repressive complex 2 subunit, is an epigenetic regulator (PMID: 29845708) and methyltransferase that functions within the polycomb repressive complex 2 to methylate histone H3 at lysine 29, which is associated with transcriptional repression (PMID: 19026780). Mutations and altered expression of EZH1 are commonly observed in hematological malignancies (PMID: 29845708).

PLK2, polo like kinase 2, is a member of the Polo-like kinase family of serine-threonine kinases that is a target of Tp53, and plays a role in DNA damage response, centriole duplication, and cell division (PMID: 30104712, PMID: 27423313, PMID: 19305416). PLK2 overexpression (PMID: 27423313) and expression loss (PMID: 29448085) has been observed in colorectal cancer, and PLK2 promoter methylation has been demonstrated in acute myeloid leukemia (PMID: 21340720).

SPINK1, serine peptidase inhibitor, Kazal type 1, is a secreted trypsin inhibitor that prevents premature activation of trypsin in the pancreas, and is also involved in growth regulation (PMID: 26656134). Germline SPINK1 mutations are associated with familial pancreatitis, and elevated Spink1 expression has been identified in a variety of cancers (PMID: 24522117, PMID: 26656134).

HNRNPH1, heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein H1, is an RNA-binding protein that regulates splicing of pre-mRNA (PMID: 27565210, PMID: 30003873). An MEF2D-HNRNPH1 fusion has been identified in B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (PMID: 30171027), and overexpression of HNRNPH1 has been identified in multiple tumor types including esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 27621578), and glioma (PMID: 21915099).

HERPUD1, homocysteine inducible ER protein with ubiquitin like domain 1, is a stress-induced ER protein that regulates degradation of misfolded proteins (PMID: 15147274). HEPRUD1-BRAF fusion is identified in pancreatic acinar cell carcinomas (PMID: 25266736).

SSBP2, single stranded DNA binding protein 2 binds to single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) and is required for DNA replication, and genomic stability (PMID: 19683501). A SSBP2 fusion with JAK2 has been observed in leukemia (PMID: 18618714) and variants have been associated with survival in glioblastoma (PMID: 22472174).

DNMT1, DNA methyltransferase 1, is a epigenetic modifier that methylates DNA during replication to preserve parental methylation patterns (PMID: 20234167, PMID: 30544982). DNMT1 overexpression is commonly observed in haematological malignancies (PMID: 20234167), including acute myeloid leukemia (PMID: 31105426).

PTPRZ1, protein tyrosine phosphatase, receptor type Z1, encodes for a receptor that is activated by Hif2a and is involved in signal transduction and primarily expressed during central nervous system development (PMID: 20224786). PTPRZ1-MET fusions have been observed in glioma (PMID: 30343896) and overexpression of PTPRZ1 has been seen in a variety of tumors, including glioblastoma, renal carcinoma, and hepatocarcinoma (PMID: 20224786).

PMS2, PMS1 homolog 2, mismatch repair system component, interacts with MLH1 to form the MutL-alpha complex, which functions in DNA mismatch repair (PMID: 18157157, PMID: 24333356) and is associated with microsatellite instability (MSI) (PMID: 30121009) and genomic stability (PMID: 31747945). Germline PMS2 mutations are associated with Lynch syndrome (PMID: 15528792), mutations in PMS2 are associated with susceptibility to colon cancer and endometrial cancer (PMID: 24978665), and overexpression has been reported in prostate cancer (PMID: 27803051).

GRIN2A, glutamate receptor, ionotropic, N-methyl D-aspartate 2A, is a subunit of the NMDA receptor, glutamate-gated ion channel (PMID: 22291485). GRIN2A is frequently mutated in melanoma, suggesting that the glutamate pathway may be involved in cancer (PMID: 21499247).

IGFBP1, insulin-like growth factor binding protein 1, is a member of the IGF-binding protein (IGFBP) family that is mainly expressed by the liver and circulates in the plasma to regulate cell migration and survival (PMID: 27152521). Aberrant expression of Igfbp1 has been observed in colorectal cancer liver metastasis (PMID: 27152521) and in endometrial cancer (PMID: 26802879).

VHL, von Hippel-Lindau tumor suppressor, is part of an E3 ubiquitin protein ligase complex, which promotes degradation of HIF-alpha and other protein targets required for cellular growth and angiogenesis (PMID: 24583008, PMID: 30194449), and plays a role in genomic stability (PMID: 31747945). VHL contributes to von Hippel-Lindau disease (PMID: 30194449, PMID: 30006056) and sporadic tumors, including clear cell renal carcinoma (PMID: 24583008, PMID: 30149673).

PWWP2A, PWWP domain containing 2A, encodes for a protein that may be involved in transcriptional regulation due to its PWWP domain (PMID: 20850016). A PWWP2A fusion with ROS1 has been observed in a melanocytic spitzoid tumor (PMID: 24445538).

MYBL1, MYB proto-oncogene like 1, encodes for a transcriptional regulatory protein that targets genes related to cell differentiation, apoptosis, and the cell cycle (PMID: 26476589). Recurrent MYBL1 fusions have been found in adenoid cystic carcinoma (PMID: 26631070).

KDM7A, lysine demethylase 7A , is a histone demethylase that regulates gene expression (PMID: 16983801, PMID: 22143793). Over expression of KDM7A may suppress tumor growth through inhibition of tumor angiogenesis (PMID: 22143793).

FGF19, fibroblast growth factor 19, is an FGF family member that function in metabolism regulation (PMID: 26308386). FGF19 over expression and amplification is associated with several tumor types (PMID: 26450751, PMID: 24728076, PMID: 25950492).

PLEKHA6, pleckstrin homology domain containing, family A member 6, may bind PtdIns3 and potentially function as an adaptor protein (PMID: 11001876). PLEKHA6 fusions have been observed with NTRK3 in langerhans cell histiocytosis (PMID: 30098202) and with NTRK1 (PMID: 29466156).

SLC16A3, solute carrier family 16 member 3 (monocarboxylic acid transporter 4), transports monocarboxylates across cell membrane, therefore regulates cellular environment and metabolism (PMID: 23506875). Increased Slc16a3 level has been detected in renal cell carcinoma, cervical and prostate cancers (PMID: 23999443).

RREB1, ras responsive element binding protein 1, is a transcription factor that regulates expression of several downstream targets and may play a role in Ras signaling (PMID: 8816445, PMID: 24418439, PMID: 21703425). RREB1 over expression has been demonstrated in colorectal cancer (PMID: 22751122)

SMAD2, SMAD family member 2, is also known as mothers against decapentaplegic homolog 2 and is a tumor suppressor (PMID: 30562755) and receptor-activated Smad protein that acts as a transcription factor to transduce TGF-beta signaling (PMID: 17340614). SMAD2 germline mutations are common in juvenile polyposis (PMID: 30562755) and somatic mutations in Smad2 have been associated with several solid tumor types (PMID: 22204491, PMID: 10822381).

STK35, serine/threonine kinase 35, is a protein localized mainly to the nucleus that plays a role in cell-cycle regulation and cell migration (PMID: 21283756, PMID: 19756140). STK35 has been identified in a fusion with BRAF in pleura mesothelioma (PMID: 26314551) and has been observed to be overexpressed in osteosarcoma (PMID: 29414823).

MYOD1, myogenic differentiation 1, is a transcription factor that plays a critical role in myogenesis (PMID: 16099183, PMID: 15930108). MYOD1 mutations are associated with spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma (PMID: 24272621, PMID: 24793135).

BCL2L2, BCL2 like 2, encodes an antiapoptotic member of the BCL2 protein family that regulates cell death via apoptotic suppression and is required for spermatogenesis (PMID: 29099482, PMID: 28094768). BCL2L2 overexpression has been identified in lymphoid malignancies (PMID: 28855351, PMID: 28094768), lung adenocarcinoma (PMID: 17459056), and colorectal adenocarcinomas (PMID: 10638987).

CD44, CD44 molecule (Indian blood group), is a cell surface adhesion molecule that plays a role in tumor cell growth and metastasis (PMID: 28326306). Over expression of CD44 is found in most epithelial originated tumors (PMID: 27200096).

SH2D1A, SH2 domain containing 1A, is an adaptor for signaling lymphocytic activation molecule (SLAM) receptor proteins, and plays a role in NK and T-cell activation (PMID: 26682762). SH2D1A mutations have been observed in X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome (PMID: 28267077, PMID: 29649976).

NQO1, NAD(P)H quinone dehydrogenase 1, encodes a flavoprotein that plays a role in the catalyzation and detoxification of quinones to hydroquinones via a two electron reduction (PMID: 11309386). Overexpression of NQO1 has been observed in a variety of cancers including lung, uterine, and pancreas (PMID: 25885439).

ZNF207, zinc finger protein 207, is a transcription factor and C2-H2 zinc-finger domain protein that is involved in regulation of kinetochore-microtubule interaction and chromosome alignment, and plays a role in cellular self-renewal (PMID: 24462187, PMID: 30349051, PMID: 25104085). A fusion of ZNF207 and ERBB2 (HER2) has been observed in gastric adenocarcinoma (PMID: 25889497).

WT1, Wilms tumor 1, encodes a transcription factor responsible for targeting genes related to cell growth and metabolism (PMID: 17361230). WT1 is known as a tumor suppressor involved in the development of Wilms' tumor of the kidney, but also demonstrates an oncogenic role in other cancers, including acute myeloid leukemia (PMID: 16987884, PMID: 17361230).

CEP89, centrosomal protein 89 kDa, is involved in activation of mitochondrial complex IV through an unknown mechanism (PMID: 23575228). CEP89 fusions have been observed with BRAF in Spitzoid melanomas (PMID: 24445538).

STK11, serine/threonine kinase 11, is a tumor suppressor (PMID: 30562755) involved in cell metabolism, growth, polarity, and tumor suppression through the regulation of AMPK family members (PMID: 26398719). STK11 germline mutations are common in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and somatic STK11 mutations have been identified in melanoma, lung, pancreatic, cervical, and endometrial cancers (PMID: 26877140, PMID: 29191602) and are often associated with resistance to immune checkpoint blockcade (PMID: 30626603).

HHAT, protein-cysteine N-palmitoyltransferase HHAT, is a member of the membrane-bound O-acyltransferase (MBOAT) family that catalyzes amino-terminal palmitoylation of sonic hedgehog (SHH) for activation (PMID: 25488661). Inhibition or knockdown of Hhat has been shown to be effective in preventing tumor cell proliferation in preclinical studies (PMID: 28408481).

PKN1, protein kinase N1, is a member of the protein kinase C superfamily that mediates Rho-dependent signaling pathways, thus regulates cell migration, invasion, and gene expression (PMID: 25504435, PMID: 28222172). Increased Pkn1 expression has been identified in glioma, kidney, ovarian, and prostate cancer, and pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PMID: 30206226).

CRP, C-reactive protein, is produce by the liver in response to low-grade inflammation (PMID: 30606716), during acute phase and systemic inflammation (PMID: 25936279). Elevated serum Crp may be prognostic in urological tumors such as, renal cell carcinoma, prostate cancer, bladder cancer, upper tract urothelial carcinoma, and penile cancer (PMID: 25936279).

NDRG1, N-myc downstream regulated 1, is a member of the NDRG family and appears to play a role in multiple biological functions including tumor suppression, cell differentiation, cell growth, lipid biosynthesis, stress response, and myelination (PMID: 25712528). NDRG1 fusions with ERG were found to be over expressed in prostate cancer (PMID: 19649210).

CTNNA1, catenin alpha 1, encodes a protein that forms part of the E-cadherin-catenin complex and functions to bind and bundle actin filaments, thereby playing a critical role in E-cadherin-mediated cell-cell adhesion (PMID: 7568023, PMID: 14570569, PMID: 17945508). Decreased Ctnna1 expression, including loss of membrane localization, has been identified in multiple solid tumors (PMID: 17945508), including pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PMID: 11911306), and colorectal carcinoma (PMID: 9894451).

TYRP1, tyrosinase related protein 1, encodes for a transmembrane glycoprotein that plays a role in the production of melanin (PMID: 21324755). TYRP1 over expression has been observed in melanoma (PMID: 22045183).

FLI1, friend leukemia integration 1 transcription factor, is a member of the Ets transcription family and is involved in embryogenesis and hematopoiesis (PMID: 11175359). The fusion protein EWSR1-FLI1 can result in malignant transformation and is commonly found in Ewing sarcoma (PMID: 19417137).

PIK3CB, phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate 3-kinase catalytic subunit beta isoform, activates AKT/mTOR signaling to promote cell proliferation (PMID: 23411347). PIK3CB mutations have been identified in breast cancer, glioblasoma, and colorectal cancer (PMID: 29326882).

DUX4, double homeobox 4, encodes for a transcription factor and is genetically associated with facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (PMID: 26816005). The fusion, CIC-DUX4, has been observed in round-cell sarcoma (PMID: 27079694) and altered expression has been reported in various sarcomas and haematological cancers (PMID: 31174839).

H2BC5, H2B clustered histone 5, is a member of the histone H2B family of proteins with limited characterization that may play a role in nucleosome assembly and cellular differentiation (PMID: 23717473). Overexpression of H2BC5 has been demonstrated in various cancers, including hepatocellular carcinoma, retinoblastoma, B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (PMID: 20621981), and is associated with survival in cervical squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 29184082).

TNFRSF17, TNF receptor superfamily member 17, is also known as B cell maturation antigen (PMID: 30147690) and encodes for a member of the TNF-receptor superfamily that is mainly present on the surface of plasma cells and plays a role in cell survival (PMID: 23776238). Increased TNFRSF17 expression has been observed on the surface of multiple myeloma cells (PMID: 26370838) and may increase the number of breast cancer stem cells (PMID: 30131941).

DAXX, death-domain associated protein 6, is a transcriptional co-regulator that represses activity of transcriptional factors including C/EBPB, c-Met, Pax3, Ets1, p53, AR, and SMAD4 (PMID: 23539629). Loss of Daxx expression has been linked to ovarian cancer and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, while overexpression has been observed in oral squamous cell carcinoma and prostate cancer (PMID: 26205068, PMID: 27162024, PMID: 23954140, PMID: 23642739).

IGHV3-21, immunoglobulin heavy variable 3-21, encodes part of the variable portion of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (PMID: 22551722). IGHV3-21 expression is associated with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (PMID: 21303354).

INPP4B, inositol polyphosphate-4-phosphatase type II B, is a lipid phosphatase that catalyzes the degradation of PI(3,4)P2, thus terminates Akt pathway signaling, and may play a role in inhibition of proliferation and migration (PMID: 26022180, PMID: 21127264). Decreased expression of INPP4B has been identified in solid tumors including prostate, ovarian, and basal-like breast cancer (PMID: 21224358, PMID: 21127264, PMID: 19647222), and in leukemia (PMID: 22072402).

TEAD1, TEA domain family member 1, is a transcription factor which functions through the Hippo pathway to regulate cell proliferation and apoptosis (PMID: 18579750). Abnormal expression of Tead1 has been identified in several cancers including prostate, pancreatic, breast, and bladder cancers (PMID: 23029054).

PIWIL1, piwi-like RNA-mediated gene silencing 1, interacts with piRNAs in transposon silencing and is required for spermatogenesis (PMID: 22996918, PMID: 21928326). PIWIL1 is overexpressed in several tumor types including ductal breast carcinoma (PMID: 29599319) and lung adenocarcinoma (PMID: 29168346), and is associated with poor prognosis (PMID: 23087701, PMID: 24932571).

SLC34A2, solute carrier family 34 member 2, encodes for a sodium phosphate co-transporter protein, which allows phosphate to be secreted into cells (PMID: 25017204). Fusions of SLC34A2 with ROS1 have been found in non-small cell lung cancer (PMID: 25688157).

XRCC2, X-ray repair cross complementing 2, is a family member of the XRCC genes that is involved in homologous recombination repair (PMID: 15279796). XRCC2 mutations have been identified in breast and skin cancers (PMID: 15723711).

ADAM17, ADAM metallopeptidase domain 17, is a member of the disintegrin and metalloprotease domain family, that functions in proteolytic processing of a number of membrane-bound substrates, including TNF-alpha and EGFR ligands, and plays a role in immunity, development, and inflammation (PMID: 31060243, PMID: 30992230). ADAM17 missense mutations have been observed in colon cancer (PMID: 31060243) and altered expression has been reported in lung cancer (PMID: 30833304).

HLA-A, HLA class I histocompatibility antigen, plays a role in the presentation of foreign antigens to the immune system (PMID: 17326240). A fusion of HLA-A with ROS1 has been observed in spitzoid neoplasms (PMID: 24445538), and HLA-A mutations have been associated with chronic myelogenous leukemia (PMID: 20388056), chronic lymphocytic leukemia (PMID: 22814293), and nasopharyngeal carcinoma (PMID: 22880099).

SLC38A3, sodium-coupled neutral amino acid transporter 3, is a sodium dependent transmembrane amino acid transporter (PMID: 10823827). Reduced Slc38a3 expression has been noted in murine models of fibrosarcoma (PMID: 16432833) and may promote metastasis in NSCLC (PMID: 28202352).

SSX2, SSX family member 2, is a putative transcriptional repressor (PMID: 27276714) and a known cancer testis antigen (CTA) (PMID: 30186454, PMID: 25363656). S18-SSX2 fusions are commonly associated with synovial sarcoma (PMID: 17018603, PMID: 26259251, PMID: 26571495, PMID: 30186454).

CCDC6, coiled-coil domain containing 6, has been shown to play a role in the DNA damaging signaling pathway acting as a substrate of ATM (PMID: 17420723). CCDC6 fusions with RET (PMID: 23154560, PMID: 26078337) and BRAF (PMID: 26314551) have been observed in multiple cancer types.

ACTA2, actin alpha 2, smooth muscle, is a conserved cytoskeletal protein involved in cell structure, motility, and smooth muscle contraction (PMID: 26934405). ACTA2 has been identified in lung adenocarcinoma where elevated expression is associated with poor prognosis (PMID: 23995859).

PTK2, protein tyrosine kinase 2, encodes for a focal adhesion tyrosine kinase, which once activated via integrins, signals various molecules involved in the regulation of cell proliferation, apoptosis, survival, and migration (PMID: 12371144). Increased activation of Ptk2 has been observed in ovarian cancer, which has been linked to PTK2 amplification (PMID: 24755674).

CDK11A, cyclin-dependent kinase 11A, is also known as CDC2L2 and is one of eleven isoforms encoding CDK11, which is also encoded by CDK11B and it is not clear which CDK11 isoforms (p46, p58, and p110) correspond to CDK11 A or B (PMID: 27049727). CDK11 plays a role in the regulation of cell growth, proliferation, and apoptosis (PMID: 24007862) and aberrant expression of Cdk11 has a role in tumor progression in multiple tumor types (PMID: 27049727, PMID: 28262798, PMID: 27207777, PMID: 26470709).

TUBB2A, tubulin beta 2A class IIa, is a component of the microtubule, which plays important roles in central nervous system development (PMID: 25008804). TUBB2A expression has been associated with peripheral neuropathy induced by Taxol (paclitaxel) (PMID: 22718863).

NOTCH4, notch receptor 4, is a transmembrane receptor, which plays a role in cell fate regulation, proliferation, and survival (PMID: 24403446). NOTCH4 overexpression in TNBC plays a role in proliferation and invasiveness (PMID: 24403446, PMID: 29805613), has been observed in tamoxifen-resistant breast cancer (PMID: 28108315) and oral squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 27197026), and may be prognostic for progression in colorectal cancer (PMID: 30026833, PMID: 29693251).

MITF, melanogenesis associated transcription factor, encodes for a transcription factor that plays a key role in the development, differentiation, and survival of melanocytes, and transcription of the HIF1A gene (PMID: 23207919, PMID: 22012259). MITF amplification has been observed in melanoma while MITF mutations, in particular germline mutations, may increase the risk for melanoma and renal cancer (PMID: 25433395, PMID: 22012259).

CCNL2, cyclin-L2, interacts with CDK11 (PMID: 18216018) may play a role in mRNA processing and transcription of apoptotic genes, thereby having a putative role as a tumor suppressor (PMID: 14684736). A CCLN2 fusion with PCMTD1 (PCMTD1-CCNL2) has been observed more commonly in endometrioid ovarian carcinomas than in other ovarian cancer subtypes (PMID: 29633253).

JAZF1, JAZF zinc finger 1, encodes a transcription factor that binds to Tak1 and acts as a negative transcriptional regulator (PMID: 26879382). JAZF1 fusion with SUZ12 is associated with endometrial stromal sarcoma (PMID: 16049311, PMID: 11371647, PMID: 18077430).

CLDN18, claudin 18, encodes a tight junction protein that lies between the epithelial cells in either the stomach or lung, forming the paracellular barrier, which prevents solutes from entering and exiting between cells (PMID: 11585919, PMID: 18987354). A fusion with ARHGAP26 has been observed in gastric cancer (PMID: 26146084) and expression of the CLDN18.2 alternative transcript has been associated with both gastric cancer and lung cancer (PMID: 24710653, PMID: 19047087).

XIAP, X-linked inhibitor of apoptosis, is a member of the inhibitor of apoptosis protein (IAP) family that suppresses apoptosis through direct inhibition of caspases (PMID: 17016456), and also acts as a ubiquitin ligase regulating signaling pathways involved in immunity and inflammation (PMID: 25666262). XIAP expression has been identified in papillary thyroid cancer (PMID: 24124924) and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (PMID: 17283363).

TERT, telomerase reverse transcriptase, encodes for one of the subunits of telomerase, thereby playing a major role in the maintenance of telomere length via reverse transcriptase activity (PMID: 16756500). TERT amplification and promoter mutations are associated with a variety of tumor types (PMID: 11103775, PMID: 23887589).

CDC42BPA, CDC42 binding protein kinase alpha, is a Serine/Threonine kinase that functions downstream of cdc42, thus regulating cytoskeleton organization and cell motility (PMID: 15723050). Elevated Cdc42bpa expression level has been correlated with metastasis and poor survival in colon cancer patients (PMID: 29072916).
AGAP3, ArfGAP with GTPase domain, ankyrin repeat and PH domain 3 is a GTPase (PMID: 16461359). AGAP3 fusions are observed with BRAF in solid tumors (PMID: 26314551).

TFG, TRK-fused gene, plays a role in regulation of intracellular trafficking, and TFG fusions have been identified in several tumor types including thyroid carcinoma and extracellular myxoid chondrosarcoma (PMID: 24692687, PMID: 16547966).

KHDRBS1, KH RNA binding domain containing signal transduction associated 1, is a member of the STAR family of RNA-binding proteins that interacts with other proteins to regulate signal transduction, and plays a role in several biological processes including mRNA processing, cell proliferation, and cell differentiation (PMID: 24287914, PMID: 15619005, PMID: 14643926, PMID: 26273626). A fusion of KHDRBS1 with NTRK3 has been observed in a pediatric spindle-cell neoplasm (PMID: 30187166).

TOP1, topoisomerase (DNA) I, is an enzyme that unwinds DNA during transcription and replication (PMID: 26287259). TOP1 gene copy number gain is commenly identified in cancers of the breast, bile duct and pancreas (PMID: 25855483, PMID: 25615400).

DAB2IP, DAB2 interacting protein, is a Ras GAP family member that binds to Dab2 therefore regulates diverse cellular processes involved in carcinogenesis and tumor progression (PMID: 26658103). Inactivation of DAB2IP has been identified in prostate, breast, gastrointestinal, lung, and bladder cancers (PMID: 26658103, PMID: 27858941).

LAG3, lymphocyte activation gene 3 protein, is expressed on activated T-cells and NK cells and binds MHC class II molecules to inhibit the immune response (PMID: 28258692). LAG3 inhibition in cancer therapy may relieve suppression of the anti-tumor immune response (PMID: 29900067, PMID: 29439955).

U2AF2, U2 small nuclear RNA auxiliary factor 2, is the large subunit of the U2 auxiliary factor, which recognizes regulatory RNA sequence motifs and initiates spliceosome assembly (PMID: 1824937, PMID: 27799531). U2AF2 mutations have been identified in a variety of hematologic and solid tumors (PMID: 28850223).

NOS2, nitric oxide synthase 2, is a calcium-independent, inducible enzyme that synthesizes nitric oxide, therefore regulates multiple signaling pathways involved in cell survival, apoptosis, angiogenesis, migration, invasion, and oxidative stress in tumor tissue and tumor microenvironment (PMID: 26335399). NOS2 expression has been identified in lung (PMID: 25056538), prostate (PMID: 9587122), breast (PMID: 10873093), bladder (PMID: 9915473), and colon cancer (PMID: 10219017).

H3C2, histone H3.1, encodes a member of the histone H3 family, and may play a role in transcription regulation, DNA repair, DNA replication, and chromosomal stability. H3C2 mutations are associated with glioma (PMID: 24242757, PMID: 22286216).

MGAM, maltase-glucoamylase, hydrolyzes oligosaccharide substrates into glucose at the brush border of the small intestine (PMID: 22058037). MGAM alterations have been identified in gastric cancer, oral squamous cell carcinoma, and non-small cell lung cancer (PMID: 17611641, PMID: 23405089, PMID: 31290993).

RB1, retinoblastoma-associated protein, is a key negative regulator of the G1 to S transition during cell division (PMID: 15084261). RB1 loss plays a role in other cellular processes, especially related to cancer such as cell survival, differentiation, senescence, and genome stability (PMID: 21295686, PMID: 23359405, PMID: 22293180).

TET2, methylcytosine dioxygenase TET2, is a tumor supressor gene and a member of the ten-eleven-translocation family of genes. TET2  is involved in hematopoesis being expressed in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells and is down regulated during differentiation (PMID: 26099018, PMID: 25510268, PMID: 27848178).
PRMT3, protein arginine methyltransferase 3, is a cytoplasmic type I arginine methyltransferase involved in posttranslational modification of proteins including ribosomal protein-S2 (PMID: 21059412).

Activins are dimeric growth and differentiation factors which belong to the transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) superfamily of structurally related signaling proteins. Activins signal through a heteromeric complex of receptor serine kinases which include at least two type I ( I and IB) and two type II (II and IIB) receptors. These receptors are all transmembrane proteins, composed of a ligand-binding extracellular domain with cysteine-rich region, a transmembrane domain, and a cytoplasmic domain with predicted serine/threonine specificity. Type I receptors are essential for signaling; and type II receptors are required for binding ligands and for expression of type I receptors. Type I and II receptors form a stable complex after ligand binding, resulting in phosphorylation of type I receptors by type II receptors. This gene encodes activin A type I receptor which signals a particular transcriptional response in concert with activin type II receptors. Mutations in this gene are associated with fibrodysplasia ossificans progressive. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].

On ligand binding, forms a receptor complex consisting of two type II and two type I transmembrane serine/threonine kinases. Type II receptors phosphorylate and activate type I receptors which autophosphorylate, then bind and activate SMAD transcriptional regulators. Receptor for activin. May be involved for left-right pattern formation during embryogenesis (By similarity)

Activins are dimeric growth and differentiation factors which belong to the transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) superfamily of structurally related signaling proteins. Activins signal through a heteromeric complex of receptor serine kinases which include at least two type I ( I and IB) and two type II (II and IIB) receptors. These receptors are all transmembrane proteins, composed of a ligand-binding extracellular domain with cysteine-rich region, a transmembrane domain, and a cytoplasmic domain with predicted serine/threonine specificity. Type I receptors are essential for signaling; and type II receptors are required for binding ligands and for expression of type I receptors. Type I and II receptors form a stable complex after ligand binding, resulting in phosphorylation of type I receptors by type II receptors. This gene encodes activin A type I receptor which signals a particular transcriptional response in concert with activin type II receptors. Mutations in this gene are associated with fibrodysplasia ossificans progressive. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
Oncogene

EML4, echinoderm microtubule associated protein like 4, plays a role in microtubule formation (PMID: 16890222). The fusion protein of EML4-ALK results in transformation activity and is present in a small percentage of patients with non-small cell lung cancer (PMID: 17625570, PMID: 23341890).

PREX2, phosphatidylinositol-3,4,5-trisphosphate dependent Rac exchange factor 2, is a Rho/Rac guanine-nucleotide exchange factor that activates Rac1, resulting in cell migration and invasion, and facilitates PI3K/AKT pathway signaling in a Rac independent manner by inhibiting Pten, thereby promoting cell proliferation (PMID: 23753921, PMID: 21925199). PREX2 mutations have been identified in melanoma (PMID: 22622578), hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 30796242), and pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PMID: 25719666).

NEGR1, neuronal growth regulator 1, encodes a cell adhesion molecule that is a member of the immunoglobulin LON family and plays a role in neuronal growth and connectivity, and may engage in cell recognition and interaction (PMID: 29479305, PMID: 25057311). Decreased expression of NEGR1 has been identified in advanced neuroblastoma (PMID: 21624008) and epithelial ovarian cancer (PMID: 16115914).

The serine-threonine protein kinase encoded by the AKT1 gene is catalytically inactive in serum-starved primary and immortalized fibroblasts. AKT1 and the related AKT2 are activated by platelet-derived growth factor. The activation is rapid and specific, and it is abrogated by mutations in the pleckstrin homology domain of AKT1. It was shown that the activation occurs through phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase. In the developing nervous system AKT is a critical mediator of growth factor-induced neuronal survival. Survival factors can suppress apoptosis in a transcription-independent manner by activating the serine/threonine kinase AKT1, which then phosphorylates and inactivates components of the apoptotic machinery. Mutations in this gene have been associated with the Proteus syndrome. Multiple alternatively spliced transcript variants have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2011].

This gene is a protooncogene that encodes a protein tyrosine kinase involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell division, adhesion, differentiation, and response to stress. The activity of the protein is negatively regulated by its SH3 domain, whereby deletion of the region encoding this domain results in an oncogene. The ubiquitously expressed protein has DNA-binding activity that is regulated by CDC2-mediated phosphorylation, suggesting a cell cycle function. This gene has been found fused to a variety of translocation partner genes in various leukemias, most notably the t(9;22) translocation that results in a fusion with the 5' end of the breakpoint cluster region gene (BCR; MIM:151410). Alternative splicing of this gene results in two transcript variants, which contain alternative first exons that are spliced to the remaining common exons. [provided by RefSeq, Aug 2014].

Non-receptor tyrosine-protein kinase that plays a role in many key processes linked to cell growth and survival such as cytoskeleton remodeling in response to extracellular stimuli, cell motility and adhesion, receptor endocytosis, autophagy, DNA damage response and apoptosis. Coordinates actin remodeling through tyrosine phosphorylation of proteins controlling cytoskeleton dynamics like WASF3 (involved in branch formation); ANXA1 (involved in membrane anchoring); DBN1, DBNL, CTTN, RAPH1 and ENAH (involved in signaling); or MAPT and PXN (microtubule-binding proteins). Phosphorylation of WASF3 is critical for the stimulation of lamellipodia formation and cell migration. Involved in the regulation of cell adhesion and motility through phosphorylation of key regulators of these processes such as BCAR1, CRK, CRKL, DOK1, EFS or NEDD9. Phosphorylates multiple receptor tyrosine kinases and more particularly promotes endocytosis of EGFR, facilitates the formation of neuromuscular synapses through MUSK, inhibits PDGFRB-mediated chemotaxis and modulates the endocytosis of activated B-cell receptor complexes. Other substrates which are involved in endocytosis regulation are the caveolin (CAV1) and RIN1. Moreover, ABL1 regulates the CBL family of ubiquitin ligases that drive receptor down-regulation and actin remodeling. Phosphorylation of CBL leads to increased EGFR stability. Involved in late-stage autophagy by regulating positively the trafficking and function of lysosomal components. ABL1 targets to mitochondria in response to oxidative stress and thereby mediates mitochondrial dysfunction and cell death. In response to oxidative stress, phosphorylates serine/threonine kinase PRKD2 at 'Tyr-717' (PubMed:28428613). ABL1 is also translocated in the nucleus where it has DNA-binding activity and is involved in DNA-damage response and apoptosis. Many substrates are known mediators of DNA repair: DDB1, DDB2, ERCC3, ERCC6, RAD9A, RAD51, RAD52 or WRN. Activates the proapoptotic pathway when the DNA damage is too severe to be repaired. Phosphorylates TP73, a primary regulator for this type of damage-induced apoptosis. Phosphorylates the caspase CASP9 on 'Tyr-153' and regulates its processing in the apoptotic response to DNA damage. Phosphorylates PSMA7 that leads to an inhibition of proteasomal activity and cell cycle transition blocks. ABL1 acts also as a regulator of multiple pathological signaling cascades during infection. Several known tyrosine-phosphorylated microbial proteins have been identified as ABL1 substrates. This is the case of A36R of Vaccinia virus, Tir (translocated intimin receptor) of pathogenic E.coli and possibly Citrobacter, CagA (cytotoxin-associated gene A) of H.pylori, or AnkA (ankyrin repeat-containing protein A) of A.phagocytophilum. Pathogens can highjack ABL1 kinase signaling to reorganize the host actin cytoskeleton for multiple purposes, like facilitating intracellular movement and host cell exit. Finally, functions as its own regulator through autocatalytic activity as well as through phosphorylation of its inhibitor, ABI1. Regulates T-cell differentiation in a TBX21-dependent manner. Phosphorylates TBX21 on tyrosine residues leading to an enhancement of its transcriptional activator activity (By similarity)

This gene encodes a member of the Abelson family of nonreceptor tyrosine protein kinases. The protein is highly similar to the c-abl oncogene 1 protein, including the tyrosine kinase, SH2 and SH3 domains, and it plays a role in cytoskeletal rearrangements through its C-terminal F-actin- and microtubule-binding sequences. This gene is expressed in both normal and tumor cells, and is involved in translocation with the ets variant 6 gene in leukemia. Multiple alternatively spliced transcript variants encoding different protein isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Nov 2009].

Non-receptor tyrosine-protein kinase that plays an ABL1-overlapping role in key processes linked to cell growth and survival such as cytoskeleton remodeling in response to extracellular stimuli, cell motility and adhesion and receptor endocytosis. Coordinates actin remodeling through tyrosine phosphorylation of proteins controlling cytoskeleton dynamics like MYH10 (involved in movement); CTTN (involved in signaling); or TUBA1 and TUBB (microtubule subunits). Binds directly F-actin and regulates actin cytoskeletal structure through its F-actin-bundling activity. Involved in the regulation of cell adhesion and motility through phosphorylation of key regulators of these processes such as CRK, CRKL, DOK1 or ARHGAP35. Adhesion-dependent phosphorylation of ARHGAP35 promotes its association with RASA1, resulting in recruitment of ARHGAP35 to the cell periphery where it inhibits RHO. Phosphorylates multiple receptor tyrosine kinases like PDGFRB and other substrates which are involved in endocytosis regulation such as RIN1. In brain, may regulate neurotransmission by phosphorylating proteins at the synapse. ABL2 acts also as a regulator of multiple pathological signaling cascades during infection. Pathogens can highjack ABL2 kinase signaling to reorganize the host actin cytoskeleton for multiple purposes, like facilitating intracellular movement and host cell exit. Finally, functions as its own regulator through autocatalytic activity as well as through phosphorylation of its inhibitor, ABI1

This gene encodes a member of the Abelson family of nonreceptor tyrosine protein kinases. The protein is highly similar to the c-abl oncogene 1 protein, including the tyrosine kinase, SH2 and SH3 domains, and it plays a role in cytoskeletal rearrangements through its C-terminal F-actin- and microtubule-binding sequences. This gene is expressed in both normal and tumor cells, and is involved in translocation with the ets variant 6 gene in leukemia. Multiple alternatively spliced transcript variants encoding different protein isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Nov 2009].
Oncogene
ABL2

This gene encodes an enzyme involved in the conversion of arachidonic acid to 12R-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid. Mutations in this gene are associated with nonbullous congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma. [provided by RefSeq, Sep 2015].

Catalyzes the regio and stereo-specific incorporation of a single molecule of dioxygen into free and esterified polyunsaturated fatty acids generating lipid hydroperoxides that can be further reduced to the corresponding hydroxy species (PubMed:9837935, PubMed:9618483, PubMed:21558561). In the skin, acts upstream of ALOXE3 on the lineolate moiety of esterified omega-hydroxyacyl-sphingosine (EOS) ceramides to produce an epoxy-ketone derivative, a crucial step in the conjugation of omega-hydroxyceramide to membrane proteins (PubMed:21558561). Therefore plays a crucial role in the synthesis of corneocytes lipid envelope and the establishment of the skin barrier to water loss (PubMed:21558561). May also play a role in the regulation of the expression of airway mucins (PubMed:22441738)

SUV39H2, suppressor of variegation 3-9 homolog 2, is also known as KMT1B and is a lysine methyltransferases that methylates histone H3K9 to regulate gene transcription (PMID: 30763986) and the cell cycle (PMID: 30719171). Overexpression of SUV39H2 has been reported in a variety of tumor types, including leukemia, lymphoma, lung, breast, colorectal, gastric, hepatocellular, and esophageal (PMID: 30719171).

This gene encodes an activin A type IB receptor. Activins are dimeric growth and differentiation factors which belong to the transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) superfamily of structurally related signaling proteins. Activins signal through a heteromeric complex of receptor serine kinases which include at least two type I and two type II receptors. This protein is a type I receptor which is essential for signaling. Mutations in this gene are associated with pituitary tumors. Alternate splicing results in multiple transcript variants.[provided by RefSeq, Jun 2010].

Transmembrane serine/threonine kinase activin type-1 receptor forming an activin receptor complex with activin receptor type-2 (ACVR2A or ACVR2B). Transduces the activin signal from the cell surface to the cytoplasm and is thus regulating a many physiological and pathological processes including neuronal differentiation and neuronal survival, hair follicle development and cycling, FSH production by the pituitary gland, wound healing, extracellular matrix production, immunosuppression and carcinogenesis. Activin is also thought to have a paracrine or autocrine role in follicular development in the ovary. Within the receptor complex, type-2 receptors (ACVR2A and/or ACVR2B) act as a primary activin receptors whereas the type-1 receptors like ACVR1B act as downstream transducers of activin signals. Activin binds to type-2 receptor at the plasma membrane and activates its serine-threonine kinase. The activated receptor type-2 then phosphorylates and activates the type-1 receptor such as ACVR1B. Once activated, the type-1 receptor binds and phosphorylates the SMAD proteins SMAD2 and SMAD3, on serine residues of the C-terminal tail. Soon after their association with the activin receptor and subsequent phosphorylation, SMAD2 and SMAD3 are released into the cytoplasm where they interact with the common partner SMAD4. This SMAD complex translocates into the nucleus where it mediates activin-induced transcription. Inhibitory SMAD7, which is recruited to ACVR1B through FKBP1A, can prevent the association of SMAD2 and SMAD3 with the activin receptor complex, thereby blocking the activin signal. Activin signal transduction is also antagonized by the binding to the receptor of inhibin-B via the IGSF1 inhibin coreceptor. ACVR1B also phosphorylates TDP2

This gene encodes an activin A type IB receptor. Activins are dimeric growth and differentiation factors which belong to the transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-beta) superfamily of structurally related signaling proteins. Activins signal through a heteromeric complex of receptor serine kinases which include at least two type I and two type II receptors. This protein is a type I receptor which is essential for signaling. Mutations in this gene are associated with pituitary tumors. Alternate splicing results in multiple transcript variants.[provided by RefSeq, Jun 2010].
Tumor Suppressor Gene
ACVR1B

This gene is a protooncogene that encodes a protein tyrosine kinase involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell division, adhesion, differentiation, and response to stress. The activity of the protein is negatively regulated by its SH3 domain, whereby deletion of the region encoding this domain results in an oncogene. The ubiquitously expressed protein has DNA-binding activity that is regulated by CDC2-mediated phosphorylation, suggesting a cell cycle function. This gene has been found fused to a variety of translocation partner genes in various leukemias, most notably the t(9;22) translocation that results in a fusion with the 5' end of the breakpoint cluster region gene (BCR; MIM:151410). Alternative splicing of this gene results in two transcript variants, which contain alternative first exons that are spliced to the remaining common exons. [provided by RefSeq, Aug 2014].
Oncogene
ABL1

This gene encodes a member of the guanine nucleotide-binding protein (G protein)-coupled receptor (GPCR) superfamily, which is subdivided into classes and subtypes. The receptors are seven-pass transmembrane proteins that respond to extracellular cues and activate intracellular signal transduction pathways. This protein, an adenosine receptor of A2A subtype, uses adenosine as the preferred endogenous agonist and preferentially interacts with the G(s) and G(olf) family of G proteins to increase intracellular cAMP levels. It plays an important role in many biological functions, such as cardiac rhythm and circulation, cerebral and renal blood flow, immune function, pain regulation, and sleep. It has been implicated in pathophysiological conditions such as inflammatory diseases and neurodegenerative disorders. Alternative splicing results in multiple transcript variants. A read-through transcript composed of the upstream SPECC1L (sperm antigen with calponin homology and coiled-coil domains 1-like) and ADORA2A (adenosine A2a receptor) gene sequence has been identified, but it is thought to be non-coding. [provided by RefSeq, Jun 2013].
Receptor for adenosine (By similarity). The activity of this receptor is mediated by G proteins which activate adenylyl cyclase (By similarity)

This gene encodes a member of the guanine nucleotide-binding protein (G protein)-coupled receptor (GPCR) superfamily, which is subdivided into classes and subtypes. The receptors are seven-pass transmembrane proteins that respond to extracellular cues and activate intracellular signal transduction pathways. This protein, an adenosine receptor of A2A subtype, uses adenosine as the preferred endogenous agonist and preferentially interacts with the G(s) and G(olf) family of G proteins to increase intracellular cAMP levels. It plays an important role in many biological functions, such as cardiac rhythm and circulation, cerebral and renal blood flow, immune function, pain regulation, and sleep. It has been implicated in pathophysiological conditions such as inflammatory diseases and neurodegenerative disorders. Alternative splicing results in multiple transcript variants.
