TRAFs are composed of an N-terminal cysteine/histidine-rich region containing zinc RING and/or zinc finger motifs; a coiled-coil (leucine zipper) motif; and a homologous region that defines the TRAF family, the TRAF domain, which is involved in self-association and receptor binding.[supplied by OMIM, Apr 2004].
Tumor Suppressor Gene
TRAF7

This gene is a member of the PDGF/VEGF growth factor family. It encodes a heparin-binding protein, which exists as a disulfide-linked homodimer. This growth factor induces proliferation and migration of vascular endothelial cells, and is essential for both physiological and pathological angiogenesis. Disruption of this gene in mice resulted in abnormal embryonic blood vessel formation. This gene is upregulated in many known tumors and its expression is correlated with tumor stage and progression. Elevated levels of this protein are found in patients with POEMS syndrome, also known as Crow-Fukase syndrome. Allelic variants of this gene have been associated with microvascular complications of diabetes 1 (MVCD1) and atherosclerosis. Alternatively spliced transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been described. There is also evidence for alternative translation initiation from upstream non-AUG (CUG) codons resulting in additional isoforms. A recent study showed that a C-terminally extended isoform is produced by use of an alternative in-frame translation termination codon via a stop codon readthrough mechanism, and that this isoform is antiangiogenic. Expression of some isoforms derived from the AUG start codon is regulated by a small upstream open reading frame, which is located within an internal ribosome entry site. [provided by RefSeq, Nov 2015].

In complex with TSC2, inhibits the nutrient-mediated or growth factor-stimulated phosphorylation of S6K1 and EIF4EBP1 by negatively regulating mTORC1 signaling (PubMed:12271141, PubMed:28215400). Seems not to be required for TSC2 GAP activity towards RHEB (PubMed:15340059). Implicated as a tumor suppressor. Involved in microtubule-mediated protein transport, but this seems to be due to unregulated mTOR signaling (By similarity). Acts as a co-chaperone for HSP90AA1 facilitating HSP90AA1 chaperoning of protein clients such as kinases, TSC2 and glucocorticoid receptor NR3C1 (PubMed:29127155). Increases ATP binding to HSP90AA1 and inhibits HSP90AA1 ATPase activity (PubMed:29127155). Competes with the activating co-chaperone AHSA1 for binding to HSP90AA1, thereby providing a reciprocal regulatory mechanism for chaperoning of client proteins (PubMed:29127155). Recruits TSC2 to HSP90AA1 and stabilizes TSC2 by preventing the interaction between TSC2 and ubiquitin ligase HERC1 (PubMed:16464865, PubMed:29127155)

This gene is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes the growth inhibitory protein hamartin. The encoded protein interacts with and stabilizes the GTPase activating protein tuberin. This hamartin-tuberin complex negatively regulates mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1 (mTORC1) signalling which is a major regulator of anabolic cell growth. This protein also functions as a co-chaperone for Hsp90 that inhibits its ATPase activity. This protein functions as a facilitator of Hsp90-mediated folding of kinase and non-kinase clients, including Tsc2 and thereby preventing their ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation. Mutations in this gene have been associated with tuberous sclerosis. [provided by RefSeq, Apr 2018].
Tumor Suppressor Gene
TSC1

This gene belongs to the splicing factor SR family of genes. U2 auxiliary factor, comprising a large and a small subunit, is a non-snRNP protein required for the binding of U2 snRNP to the pre-mRNA branch site. This gene encodes the small subunit which plays a critical role in both constitutive and enhancer-dependent RNA splicing by directly mediating interactions between the large subunit and proteins bound to the enhancers. Alternatively spliced transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been identified. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
TSC2

Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (VHL) is a dominantly inherited familial cancer syndrome predisposing to a variety of malignant and benign tumors. A germline mutation of this gene is the basis of familial inheritance of VHL syndrome. The protein encoded by this gene is a component of the protein complex that includes elongin B, elongin C, and cullin-2, and possesses ubiquitin ligase E3 activity. This protein is involved in the ubiquitination and degradation of hypoxia-inducible-factor (HIF), which is a transcription factor that plays a central role in the regulation of gene expression by oxygen. RNA polymerase II subunit POLR2G/RPB7 is also reported to be a target of this protein. Alternatively spliced transcript variants encoding distinct isoforms have been observed. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].

Involved in the ubiquitination and subsequent proteasomal degradation via the von Hippel-Lindau ubiquitination complex. Seems to act as a target recruitment subunit in the E3 ubiquitin ligase complex and recruits hydroxylated hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) under normoxic conditions. Involved in transcriptional repression through interaction with HIF1A, HIF1AN and histone deacetylases. Ubiquitinates, in an oxygen-responsive manner, ADRB2

Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (VHL) is a dominantly inherited familial cancer syndrome predisposing to a variety of malignant and benign tumors. A germline mutation of this gene is the basis of familial inheritance of VHL syndrome. The protein encoded by this gene is a component of the protein complex that includes elongin B, elongin C, and cullin-2, and possesses ubiquitin ligase E3 activity. This protein is involved in the ubiquitination and degradation of hypoxia-inducible-factor (HIF), which is a transcription factor that plays a central role in the regulation of gene expression by oxygen. RNA polymerase II subunit POLR2G/RPB7 is also reported to be a target of this protein. Alternatively spliced transcript variants encoding distinct isoforms have been observed. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
Tumor Suppressor Gene
VHL

This gene encodes a protein that belongs to a family of apoptotic suppressor proteins. Members of this family share a conserved motif termed, baculovirus IAP repeat, which is necessary for their anti-apoptotic function. This protein functions through binding to tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factors TRAF1 and TRAF2 and inhibits apoptosis induced by menadione, a potent inducer of free radicals, and interleukin 1-beta converting enzyme. This protein also inhibits at least two members of the caspase family of cell-death proteases, caspase-3 and caspase-7. Mutations in this gene are the cause of X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome. Alternate splicing results in multiple transcript variants. Pseudogenes of this gene are found on chromosomes 2 and 11.[provided by RefSeq, Feb 2011].

Multi-functional protein which regulates not only caspases and apoptosis, but also modulates inflammatory signaling and immunity, copper homeostasis, mitogenic kinase signaling, cell proliferation, as well as cell invasion and metastasis. Acts as a direct caspase inhibitor. Directly bind to the active site pocket of CASP3 and CASP7 and obstructs substrate entry. Inactivates CASP9 by keeping it in a monomeric, inactive state. Acts as an E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase regulating NF-kappa-B signaling and the target proteins for its E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase activity include: RIPK1, CASP3, CASP7, CASP8, CASP9, MAP3K2/MEKK2, DIABLO/SMAC, AIFM1, CCS and BIRC5/survivin. Ubiquitinion of CCS leads to enhancement of its chaperone activity toward its physiologic target, SOD1, rather than proteasomal degradation. Ubiquitinion of MAP3K2/MEKK2 and AIFM1 does not lead to proteasomal degradation. Plays a role in copper homeostasis by ubiquitinationg COMMD1 and promoting its proteasomal degradation. Can also function as E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase of the NEDD8 conjugation pathway, targeting effector caspases for neddylation and inactivation. Regulates the BMP signaling pathway and the SMAD and MAP3K7/TAK1 dependent pathways leading to NF-kappa-B and JNK activation. Acts as an important regulator of innate immune signaling via regulation of Nodlike receptors (NLRs). Protects cells from spontaneous formation of the ripoptosome, a large multi-protein complex that has the capability to kill cancer cells in a caspase-dependent and caspase-independent manner. Suppresses ripoptosome formation by ubiquitinating RIPK1 and CASP8. Acts as a positive regulator of Wnt signaling and ubiquitinates TLE1, TLE2, TLE3, TLE4 and AES. Ubiquitination of TLE3 results in inhibition of its interaction with TCF7L2/TCF4 thereby allowing efficient recruitment and binding of the transcriptional coactivator beta-catenin to TCF7L2/TCF4 that is required to initiate a Wnt-specific transcriptional program

This gene encodes a protein that belongs to a family of apoptotic suppressor proteins. Members of this family share a conserved motif termed, baculovirus IAP repeat, which is necessary for their anti-apoptotic function. This protein functions through binding to tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factors TRAF1 and TRAF2 and inhibits apoptosis induced by menadione, a potent inducer of free radicals, and interleukin 1-beta converting enzyme. This protein also inhibits at least two members of the caspase family of cell-death proteases, caspase-3 and caspase-7. Mutations in this gene are the cause of X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome. Alternate splicing results in multiple transcript variants. Pseudogenes of this gene are found on chromosomes 2 and 11.[provided by RefSeq, Feb 2011].
Neither
XIAP

The protein encoded by this gene is a membrane protein and a major controller of thyroid cell metabolism. The encoded protein is a receptor for thyrothropin and thyrostimulin, and its activity is mediated by adenylate cyclase. Defects in this gene are a cause of several types of hyperthyroidism. Three transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Dec 2008].
Oncogene
TSHR

This gene is the cellular homolog of the Yamaguchi sarcoma virus oncogene. The encoded protein has tyrosine kinase activity and belongs to the src family of proteins. This gene lies in close proximity to thymidylate synthase gene on chromosome 18, and a corresponding pseudogene has been found on chromosome 22. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].

Non-receptor protein tyrosine kinase that is involved in the regulation of cell growth and survival, apoptosis, cell-cell adhesion, cytoskeleton remodeling, and differentiation. Stimulation by receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) including EGRF, PDGFR, CSF1R and FGFR leads to recruitment of YES1 to the phosphorylated receptor, and activation and phosphorylation of downstream substrates. Upon EGFR activation, promotes the phosphorylation of PARD3 to favor epithelial tight junction assembly. Participates in the phosphorylation of specific junctional components such as CTNND1 by stimulating the FYN and FER tyrosine kinases at cell-cell contacts. Upon T-cell stimulation by CXCL12, phosphorylates collapsin response mediator protein 2/DPYSL2 and induces T-cell migration. Participates in CD95L/FASLG signaling pathway and mediates AKT-mediated cell migration. Plays a role in cell cycle progression by phosphorylating the cyclin-dependent kinase 4/CDK4 thus regulating the G1 phase. Also involved in G2/M progression and cytokinesis

Plays a critical role in both constitutive and enhancer-dependent splicing by mediating protein-protein interactions and protein-RNA interactions required for accurate 3'-splice site selection. Recruits U2 snRNP to the branch point. Directly mediates interactions between U2AF2 and proteins bound to the enhancers and thus may function as a bridge between U2AF2 and the enhancer complex to recruit it to the adjacent intron

This gene belongs to the splicing factor SR family of genes. U2 auxiliary factor, comprising a large and a small subunit, is a non-snRNP protein required for the binding of U2 snRNP to the pre-mRNA branch site. This gene encodes the small subunit which plays a critical role in both constitutive and enhancer-dependent RNA splicing by directly mediating interactions between the large subunit and proteins bound to the enhancers. Alternatively spliced transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been identified. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
Oncogene
U2AF1

This cell-cycle-regulated gene encodes a protein that mediates leucine-rich nuclear export signal (NES)-dependent protein transport. The protein specifically inhibits the nuclear export of Rev and U snRNAs. It is involved in the control of several cellular processes by controlling the localization of cyclin B, MPAK, and MAPKAP kinase 2. This protein also regulates NFAT and AP-1. [provided by RefSeq, Jan 2015].

Mediates the nuclear export of cellular proteins (cargos) bearing a leucine-rich nuclear export signal (NES) and of RNAs. In the nucleus, in association with RANBP3, binds cooperatively to the NES on its target protein and to the GTPase RAN in its active GTP-bound form (Ran-GTP). Docking of this complex to the nuclear pore complex (NPC) is mediated through binding to nucleoporins. Upon transit of a nuclear export complex into the cytoplasm, disassembling of the complex and hydrolysis of Ran-GTP to Ran-GDP (induced by RANBP1 and RANGAP1, respectively) cause release of the cargo from the export receptor. The directionality of nuclear export is thought to be conferred by an asymmetric distribution of the GTP- and GDP-bound forms of Ran between the cytoplasm and nucleus. Involved in U3 snoRNA transport from Cajal bodies to nucleoli. Binds to late precursor U3 snoRNA bearing a TMG cap

This cell-cycle-regulated gene encodes a protein that mediates leucine-rich nuclear export signal (NES)-dependent protein transport. The protein specifically inhibits the nuclear export of Rev and U snRNAs. It is involved in the control of several cellular processes by controlling the localization of cyclin B, MPAK, and MAPKAP kinase 2. This protein also regulates NFAT and AP-1. [provided by RefSeq, Jan 2015].
Oncogene
XPO1
chromosome: 20 from 52183604 to 52226446

Growth factor active in angiogenesis, vasculogenesis and endothelial cell growth. Induces endothelial cell proliferation, promotes cell migration, inhibits apoptosis and induces permeabilization of blood vessels. Binds to the FLT1/VEGFR1 and KDR/VEGFR2 receptors, heparan sulfate and heparin. NRP1/Neuropilin-1 binds isoforms VEGF-165 and VEGF-145. Isoform VEGF165B binds to KDR but does not activate downstream signaling pathways, does not activate angiogenesis and inhibits tumor growth. Binding to NRP1 receptor initiates a signaling pathway needed for motor neuron axon guidance and cell body migration, including for the caudal migration of facial motor neurons from rhombomere 4 to rhombomere 6 during embryonic development (By similarity)

This gene is a member of the PDGF/VEGF growth factor family. It encodes a heparin-binding protein, which exists as a disulfide-linked homodimer. This growth factor induces proliferation and migration of vascular endothelial cells, and is essential for both physiological and pathological angiogenesis. Disruption of this gene in mice resulted in abnormal embryonic blood vessel formation. This gene is upregulated in many known tumors and its expression is correlated with tumor stage and progression. Elevated levels of this protein are found in patients with POEMS syndrome, also known as Crow-Fukase syndrome. Allelic variants of this gene have been associated with microvascular complications of diabetes 1 (MVCD1) and atherosclerosis. Alternatively spliced transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been described. There is also evidence for alternative translation initiation from upstream non-AUG (CUG) codons resulting in additional isoforms. A recent study showed that a C-terminally extended isoform is produced by use of an alternative in-frame translation termination codon via a stop codon readthrough mechanism, and that this isoform is antiangiogenic. Expression of some isoforms derived from the AUG start codon is regulated by a small upstream open reading frame, which is located within an internal ribosome entry site. [provided by RefSeq, Nov 2015].
Neither
VEGFA

This gene encodes a member of the WNT1 inducible signaling pathway (WISP) protein subfamily, which belongs to the connective tissue growth factor (CTGF) family. WNT1 is a member of a family of cysteine-rich, glycosylated signaling proteins that mediate diverse developmental processes. The CTGF family members are characterized by four conserved cysteine-rich domains: insulin-like growth factor-binding domain, von Willebrand factor type C module, thrombospondin domain and C-terminal cystine knot-like domain. This gene is overexpressed in colon tumors. It may be downstream in the WNT1 signaling pathway that is relevant to malignant transformation. Mutations of this gene are associated with progressive pseudorheumatoid dysplasia, an autosomal recessive skeletal disorder, indicating that the gene is essential for normal postnatal skeletal growth and cartilage homeostasis. Multiple transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].

Plays a role in mitochondrial electron transport and mitochondrial respiration (PubMed:27252383). Through its regulation of the mitochondrial function may play a role in normal postnatal skeletal growth and cartilage homeostasis (PubMed:27252383, PubMed:10471507)

Negatively regulates T-cell-mediated immune response by inhibiting T-cell activation, proliferation, cytokine production and development of cytotoxicity. When expressed on the cell surface of tumor macrophages, plays an important role, together with regulatory T-cells (Treg), in the suppression of tumor-associated antigen-specific T-cell immunity. Involved in promoting epithelial cell transformation

This gene encodes a protein belonging to the B7 costimulatory protein family. Proteins in this family are present on the surface of antigen-presenting cells and interact with ligand bound to receptors on the surface of T cells. Studies have shown that high levels of the encoded protein has been correlated with tumor progression. A pseudogene of this gene is located on chromosome 20. Multiple transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Dec 2011].
Neither
VTCN1

This gene encodes a transcription factor that contains four zinc-finger motifs at the C-terminus and a proline/glutamine-rich DNA-binding domain at the N-terminus. It has an essential role in the normal development of the urogenital system, and it is mutated in a small subset of patients with Wilms tumor. This gene exhibits complex tissue-specific and polymorphic imprinting pattern, with biallelic, and monoallelic expression from the maternal and paternal alleles in different tissues. Multiple transcript variants have been described. In several variants, there is evidence for the use of a non-AUG (CUG) translation initiation codon upstream of, and in-frame with the first AUG. Authors of PMID:7926762 also provide evidence that WT1 mRNA undergoes RNA editing in human and rat, and that this process is tissue-restricted and developmentally regulated. [provided by RefSeq, Mar 2015].

Transcription factor that plays an important role in cellular development and cell survival (PubMed:7862533). Recognizes and binds to the DNA sequence 5'-GCG(T/G)GGGCG-3' (PubMed:7862533, PubMed:17716689, PubMed:25258363). Regulates the expression of numerous target genes, including EPO. Plays an essential role for development of the urogenital system. It has a tumor suppressor as well as an oncogenic role in tumor formation. Function may be isoform-specific: isoforms lacking the KTS motif may act as transcription factors (PubMed:15520190). Isoforms containing the KTS motif may bind mRNA and play a role in mRNA metabolism or splicing (PubMed:16934801). Isoform 1 has lower affinity for DNA, and can bind RNA (PubMed:19123921)

This gene encodes a member of the WNT1 inducible signaling pathway (WISP) protein subfamily, which belongs to the connective tissue growth factor (CTGF) family. WNT1 is a member of a family of cysteine-rich, glycosylated signaling proteins that mediate diverse developmental processes. The CTGF family members are characterized by four conserved cysteine-rich domains: insulin-like growth factor-binding domain, von Willebrand factor type C module, thrombospondin domain and C-terminal cystine knot-like domain. This gene is overexpressed in colon tumors. It may be downstream in the WNT1 signaling pathway that is relevant to malignant transformation. Mutations of this gene are associated with progressive pseudorheumatoid dysplasia, an autosomal recessive skeletal disorder, indicating that the gene is essential for normal postnatal skeletal growth and cartilage homeostasis. Multiple transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
Neither
WISP3

BCR, BCR activator of RhoGEF and GTPase, is a serine-threonine protein kinase, which may be involved in cell regulation and signaling (PMID: 15494376). BCR fuses with ABL and results in constitutive kinase activity, however overexpression of BCR inhibits cell proliferation (PMID: 15494376; PMID: 18851712).

CDH1, cadherin 1, type 1, encodes E-Cadherin and is a tumor suppressor (PMID: 30562755). Cadherin's assist in calcium dependent epithelial cell-cell adhesion (PMID: 31853199), and are involved in cell signaling, differentiation, and polarity (PMID: 18726070, PMID: 26674224).

CD8 is encoded by two distinct chains, CD8alpha and CD8beta, and is expressed on the surface of T cells primarily as a CD8alphabeta heterodimer (PMID:17145893). Heterodimeric CD8alphabeta has consistently been shown to be a better coreceptor than homodimeric CD8alphaalpha and correlates with enhanced sensitivity to peptide antigen (PMID:17145893). In addition upregulation of CD8beta is a TIL marker (PMID: 30387832)
CDKN2C,p18,p18-INK4C

CTCF, CCCTC-binding factor (zinc finger protein), is a DNA binding transcriptional repressor with distinct molecular functions such as transcription activation and repression, and enhancer blocking activity (PMID: 21465478). Additionally, CTCF is involved in long-range genome processes such as nuclear organization and chromosome segregation (PMID: 21465478; PMID: 27638884).
FH, fumarate hydratase, is an citric acid cycle enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of fumarate to malate and plays a role in mitochondria function (PMID: 25864878; PMID: 31085323).

FLT4, fms related receptor tyrosine kinase 4, encodes a tyrosine kinase receptor for VEGFC and VEGFD and plays a role in the regulation of angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis (PMID: 11114740). Lymphatic endothelial cells (key to the vascular network) require the VEGFC/FLT4/PROX1 signaling axis for their migration, proliferation, and differentiation (PMID: 30006544).

GID4, GID complex subunit 4 homolog, encodes a subunit of the C-terminal to LisH complex, and is tightly regulated on the transcriptional and protein level to ensure proper adjustment of gluconeogenesis (PMID: 30136317).

This gene encodes a transcription factor that contains four zinc-finger motifs at the C-terminus and a proline/glutamine-rich DNA-binding domain at the N-terminus. It has an essential role in the normal development of the urogenital system, and it is mutated in a small subset of patients with Wilms tumor. This gene exhibits complex tissue-specific and polymorphic imprinting pattern, with biallelic, and monoallelic expression from the maternal and paternal alleles in different tissues. Multiple transcript variants have been described. In several variants, there is evidence for the use of a non-AUG (CUG) translation initiation codon upstream of, and in-frame with the first AUG. Authors of PMID:7926762 also provide evidence that WT1 mRNA undergoes RNA editing in human and rat, and that this process is tissue-restricted and developmentally regulated. [provided by RefSeq, Mar 2015].
Tumor Suppressor Gene
WT1

This gene encodes a downstream nuclear effector of the Hippo signaling pathway which is involved in development, growth, repair, and homeostasis. This gene is known to play a role in the development and progression of multiple cancers as a transcriptional regulator of this signaling pathway and may function as a potential target for cancer treatment. Alternative splicing results in multiple transcript variants encoding different isoforms. [provided by RefSeq, Aug 2013].

Transcriptional regulator which can act both as a coactivator and a corepressor and is the critical downstream regulatory target in the Hippo signaling pathway that plays a pivotal role in organ size control and tumor suppression by restricting proliferation and promoting apoptosis (PubMed:17974916, PubMed:18280240, PubMed:18579750, PubMed:21364637, PubMed:30447097). The core of this pathway is composed of a kinase cascade wherein STK3/MST2 and STK4/MST1, in complex with its regulatory protein SAV1, phosphorylates and activates LATS1/2 in complex with its regulatory protein MOB1, which in turn phosphorylates and inactivates YAP1 oncoprotein and WWTR1/TAZ (PubMed:18158288). Plays a key role in tissue tension and 3D tissue shape by regulating cortical actomyosin network formation. Acts via ARHGAP18, a Rho GTPase activating protein that suppresses F-actin polymerization (PubMed:25778702). Plays a key role to control cell proliferation in response to cell contact. Phosphorylation of YAP1 by LATS1/2 inhibits its translocation into the nucleus to regulate cellular genes important for cell proliferation, cell death, and cell migration (PubMed:18158288). The presence of TEAD transcription factors are required for it to stimulate gene expression, cell growth, anchorage-independent growth, and epithelial mesenchymal transition (EMT) induction (PubMed:18579750)

This gene encodes a downstream nuclear effector of the Hippo signaling pathway which is involved in development, growth, repair, and homeostasis. This gene is known to play a role in the development and progression of multiple cancers as a transcriptional regulator of this signaling pathway and may function as a potential target for cancer treatment. Alternative splicing results in multiple transcript variants encoding different isoforms. [provided by RefSeq, Aug 2013].
Neither
YAP1

This gene encodes an essential splicing factor. The encoded protein associates with the U2 auxiliary factor heterodimer, which is required for the recognition of a functional 3' splice site in pre-mRNA splicing, and may play a role in network interactions during spliceosome assembly. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].

Pre-mRNA-binding protein required for splicing of both U2- and U12-type introns. Selectively interacts with the 3'-splice site of U2- and U12-type pre-mRNAs and promotes different steps in U2 and U12 intron splicing. Recruited to U12 pre-mRNAs in an ATP-dependent manner and is required for assembly of the prespliceosome, a precursor to other spliceosomal complexes. For U2-type introns, it is selectively and specifically required for the second step of splicing

This gene encodes an essential splicing factor. The encoded protein associates with the U2 auxiliary factor heterodimer, which is required for the recognition of a functional 3' splice site in pre-mRNA splicing, and may play a role in network interactions during spliceosome assembly. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].

This gene is the cellular homolog of the Yamaguchi sarcoma virus oncogene. The encoded protein has tyrosine kinase activity and belongs to the src family of proteins. This gene lies in close proximity to thymidylate synthase gene on chromosome 18, and a corresponding pseudogene has been found on chromosome 22. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
Neither
YES1

This gene encodes a transcription factor with multiple homeodomains and zinc finger motifs, and regulates myogenic and neuronal differentiation. The encoded protein suppresses expression of the alpha-fetoprotein gene by binding to an AT-rich enhancer motif. The protein has also been shown to negatively regulate c-Myb, and transactivate the cell cycle inhibitor cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 1A (also known as p21CIP1). This gene is reported to function as a tumor suppressor in several cancers, and sequence variants of this gene are also associated with atrial fibrillation. Multiple transcript variants expressed from alternate promoters and encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Sep 2009].

Transcriptional regulator which can act as an activator or a repressor. Inhibits the enhancer element of the AFP gene by binding to its AT-rich core sequence. In concert with SMAD-dependent TGF-beta signaling can repress the transcription of AFP via its interaction with SMAD2/3 (PubMed:25105025). Regulates the circadian locomotor rhythms via transcriptional activation of neuropeptidergic genes which are essential for intercellular synchrony and rhythm amplitude in the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) of the brain (By similarity). Regulator of myoblasts differentiation through the binding to the AT-rich sequence of MYF6 promoter and promoter repression (PubMed:11312261). Down-regulates the MUC5AC promoter in gastric cancer (PubMed:17330845). In association with RUNX3, upregulates CDKN1A promoter activity following TGF-beta stimulation (PubMed:20599712). Inhibits estrogen receptor (ESR1) function by selectively competing with coactivator NCOA3 for binding to ESR1 in ESR1-positive breast cancer cells (PubMed:20720010)
chromosome: 6 from 151685252 to 151712683
May be involved in transcriptional regulation
chromosome: 6 from 151685252 to 151712683
Neither
ZBTB2
chromosome: 8 from 37553269 to 37557537

Transcriptional corepressor which does not bind directly to DNA and may regulate transcription through recruitment of histone deacetylases to gene promoters. Regulates cell adhesion, migration and proliferation. May be required for segmental gene expression during hindbrain development
chromosome: 8 from 37553269 to 37557537
Neither
ZNF703

ANXA5, annexin A5, encodes a phospholipid-binding protein in the�Annexin family and is involved in cell membrane repair (PMID: 27286750, PMID: 25701430). Overexpression of ANXA5 has been observed�in hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 29802377) and colorectal cancer (PMID: 19461527), and a fusion of ANXA5 with CCNA2 has been identified in endometrioid�ovarian�carcinoma (PMID: 29633253).

DNMT3B, DNA methyltransferase 3 beta, is a de novo DNA methyltransferase involved in establishing methylation state during development (PMID: 24822169). DNMT3B is overexpressed in several tumor types, and is associated with hypermethylation in tumor pathogenesis (PMID: 24822169), and amplification and overespression has been observed in colorectal cancer (PMID: 32058953).
chromosome: 19 from 4044362 to 4066943

Transcription factor that represses the transcription of a wide range of genes involved in cell proliferation and differentiation (PubMed:14701838, PubMed:17595526, PubMed:20812024, PubMed:25514493, PubMed:26455326, PubMed:26816381). Directly and specifically binds to the consensus sequence 5'-[GA][CA]GACCCCCCCCC-3' and represses transcription both by regulating the organization of chromatin and through the direct recruitment of transcription factors to gene regulatory regions (PubMed:12004059, PubMed:17595526, PubMed:20812024, PubMed:25514493, PubMed:26816381). Negatively regulates SMAD4 transcriptional activity in the TGF-beta signaling pathway through these two mechanisms (PubMed:25514493). That is, recruits the chromatin regulator HDAC1 to the SMAD4-DNA complex and in parallel prevents the recruitment of the transcriptional activators CREBBP and EP300 (PubMed:25514493). Collaborates with transcription factors like RELA to modify the accessibility of gene transcription regulatory regions to secondary transcription factors (By similarity). Also directly interacts with transcription factors like SP1 to prevent their binding to DNA (PubMed:12004059). Functions as an androgen receptor/AR transcriptional corepressor by recruiting NCOR1 and NCOR2 to the androgen response elements/ARE on target genes (PubMed:20812024). Thereby, negatively regulates androgen receptor signaling and androgen-induced cell proliferation (PubMed:20812024). Involved in the switch between fetal and adult globin expression during erythroid cells maturation (PubMed:26816381). Through its interaction with the NuRD complex regulates chromatin at the fetal globin genes to repress their transcription (PubMed:26816381). Specifically represses the transcription of the tumor suppressor ARF isoform from the CDKN2A gene (By similarity). Efficiently abrogates E2F1-dependent CDKN2A transactivation (By similarity). Regulates chondrogenesis through the transcriptional repression of specific genes via a mechanism that also requires histone deacetylation (By similarity). Regulates cell proliferation through the transcriptional regulation of genes involved in glycolysis (PubMed:26455326). Involved in adipogenesis through the regulation of genes involved in adipocyte differentiation (PubMed:14701838). Plays a key role in the differentiation of lymphoid progenitors into B and T lineages (By similarity). Promotes differentiation towards the B lineage by inhibiting the T-cell instructive Notch signaling pathway through the specific transcriptional repression of Notch downstream target genes (By similarity). Also regulates osteoclast differentiation (By similarity). May also play a role, independently of its transcriptional activity, in double-strand break repair via classical non-homologous end joining/cNHEJ (By similarity). Recruited to double-strand break sites on damage DNA, interacts with the DNA-dependent protein kinase complex and directly regulates its stability and activity in DNA repair (By similarity). May also modulate the splicing activity of KHDRBS1 toward BCL2L1 in a mechanism which is histone deacetylase-dependent and thereby negatively regulates the pro-apoptotic effect of KHDRBS1 (PubMed:24514149)
chromosome: 19 from 4044362 to 4066943
Neither
ZBTB7A

CCNJ, cyclin J, is a putative regulator of the cell-cycle (PMID: 25672416). CCNJ promoter hypermethylation and subsequent decreased expression have been associated with worse overall survival in hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 25672416).

TEAD2, TEA domain family member 2, is a transcription factor which functions through the YAP1-Hippo pathway to regulate cell proliferation and apoptosis (PMID: 18579750, PMID: 31485614). Abnormal expression of Tead2 has been reported in gastric and colorectal cancers (PMID: 25557945).

IFIT2, interferon-induced protein with tetratricopeptide repeats 2, is a member of the IRF-inducible gene family that plays a role in the immune defense against RNA viruses and promotes apoptosis (PMID: 30234477, PMID: 31921891). Decreased expression of Ifit2 in gastric cancer and non-small cell lung cancer has been associated with tumor progression and poor prognosis (PMID: 29316541, PMID: 31632065).

EXO1, exonuclease 1, is a member of the Rad2/XPG nuclease family that plays a role in DNA replication, checkpoint progression, and DNA repair (PMID: 27098756, PMID: 30585186, PMID: 25956862). EXO1 overexpression has been observed in hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 30328366) and EXO1 mutations have been identified in breast cancer (PMID: 30947698) and pancreatic cancer (PMID: 29940740).

TMEM82, transmembrane protein 82, is a transmembrane-domain containing protein with uncharacterized physiological function, which has been identified as a potential biomarker for hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 24141781). Decreased expression of TMEM82 has been observed in hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 31086582).

This gene encodes a transcription factor with multiple homeodomains and zinc finger motifs, and regulates myogenic and neuronal differentiation. The encoded protein suppresses expression of the alpha-fetoprotein gene by binding to an AT-rich enhancer motif. The protein has also been shown to negatively regulate c-Myb, and transactivate the cell cycle inhibitor cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 1A (also known as p21CIP1). This gene is reported to function as a tumor suppressor in several cancers, and sequence variants of this gene are also associated with atrial fibrillation. Multiple transcript variants expressed from alternate promoters and encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Sep 2009].
Tumor Suppressor Gene
ZFHX3

AGO4, argonaute RISC component 4, is one of four members of the Argonaute (AGO) protein family that regulate micro-RNA (miRNA) mediated gene silencing (PMID: 18771919, PMID: 27518285) and AGO4 may also play a role in antiviral defense (PMID: 32049003) and methylation of miRNA's in conjunction with DNMT3A (PMID: 32098627). AGO4 has been demonstrated to be downregulated in hepatocellular cancer (PMID: 23398123) and overexpressed in colon cancer (PMID: 20146808).
Binds to the promoters of target genes and functions as repressor. Promotes cell proliferation and antagonizes cell death. Promotes phosphorylation of AKT1 at 'Ser-473'
chromosome: 20 from 52183604 to 52226446
Oncogene
ZNF217

CCNI2, cyclin I family member 2, interacts and activates Cdk5 in the cytoplasm and cell membrane, and likely plays a role in cell cycle progression and cell proliferation (PMID: 28112194). Decreased expression of Ccni2 decreases cell proliferation in cell culture (PMID: 28112194).

FXR1, FMR1 autosomal homolog 1, is an RNA-binding protein that regulates expression of genes involved in cell differentiation, development, and immune response (PMID: 27458872). Elevated expression of Fxr1 has been detected in head and neck squamous cell cancer, colorectal cancer, and lung cancer (PMID: 30755307, PMID: 26404134, PMID: 25733852), and a fusion with BRAF has been identified in pediatric low-grade gliomas (PMID: 29156677).
Tumor Suppressor Gene
ZRSR2

SLFN11, schlafen family member 11, encodes for a protein that plays a role in inhibiting the DNA damage response by binding to and destabilizing replication protein A1, a component of the single-stranded DNA binding protein complex (PMID: 26658330). SLFN11 expression is variable among tumor types; however, SLFN11 overexpression is associated with increased sensitivity to DNA damaging agents while decreased expression is linked to resistance (PMID: 22927417, PMID: 26658330, PMID: 27708213, PMID: 32127465), and SLFN11 gene methylation has been observed in gastric cancer (PMID: 31762822).

ERG, ETS transcription factor ERG, encodes for a transcription factor that is a member of the ETS family and plays a role in developmental processes, apoptosis, cell proliferation, angiogenesis and differentiation in endothelial and hematopoietic cells (PMID: 22279422). Fusions of TMPRSS2-ERG are common in prostate cancer (PMID: 22279422, PMID: 28849022) and an ELF4-ERG has been identified in acute myeloid leukemia (PMID: 16303180).

NRF1, nuclear respiratory factor 1, is a transcription factor that regulates expression of genes involved in mitochondrial biogenesis and functions in cell-cycle progression (PMID: 30486409, PMID: 29149604) and cellular homeostasis (PMID: 30267745). Overexpression of Nrf1 has been observed in breast cancer (PMID: 30486409) and an NRF1-BRAF fusion has been reported in pleomorphic xanthoastrocytoma (PMID: 27624885).

SDCBP, syndecan binding protein, is an adapter protein at the adherens junction that plays a role in cell adhesion, ubiquitination, synaptic development, immune regulation, exosome biogenesis, and metastasis (PMID: 26291527). Expression of Sdcbp has been observed to promote metastasis (PMID: 32061839) in a variety of tumor types, including TNBC (PMID: 29845474), HNSCC (PMID: 27811365), prostate (PMID: 29572229), and glioma (PMID: 29118922).

TFEB, transcription factor EB, is a transcription factor that regulates lysosomal function and biogenesis, thus involves in cellular response to stress conditions (PMID: 27298091). TFEB fusions have been identified in a subset of renal cell carcinoma (PMID:  27298091) and amplification has also been observed in renal cell carcinoma (PMID: 30269777).

BARD1, BRCA1 associated RING domain 1, forms a heterodimer with Brca1, which functions as an E3 ubiquitin ligase and mediator of DNA repair through homology-directed repair (HDR) (PMID: 8944023, PMID: 30925164) and centrosome regulation (PMID: 29858377). Germline mutations in BARD1 are associated with increased susceptibility to breast and ovarian cancers (PMID: 21344236), somatic mutations are highest in colon and endometrial cancers (PMID: 27283171) and BARD1 has also been implicated in neuroblastoma (PMID: 32047556).

SMG6, SMG6 nonsense mediated mRNA decay factor, is a subunit of the telomerase ribonucleoprotein (RNP) complex and may play a role in regulation of telomere length (PMID: 12699629) and nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (PMID: 20930030). A SMG6 fusion with ALK has been observed in lung adenocarcinoma (PMID: 29667179).

PRKAR1A, protein kinase cAMP-dependent type I regulatory subunit alpha, is a major component of Pka which mediates cAMP-dependent signaling (PMID: 26042218). Inactivation of PRKAR1A is associated with the familial syndrome of Carney complex (PMID: 20301463, PMID: 30699069), adrenocortical tumors (PMID: 26042218), and melanoma (PMID: 32118628).

A1CF, APOBEC1 complementation factor, is an RNA binding protein and part of a complex which edits the mRNA of apolipoprotein B (PMID: 11871661, PMID: 31881249). Deletion of an eight amino acid motif in the nuclear localization domain of A1cf has been demonstrated to promote breast cancer proliferation in culture (PMID: 27231908) and decreased expression increased apoptosis of breast cancer cells in culture (PMID: 28639893) and in Wilms tumor cell models, overexpression of A1cf decreased apoptosis (PMID: 30825095).

CEP85L, centrosomal protein 85 like, plays a role in maintenance of centrosome integrity through regulation of Nek2a activity (PMID: 26220856). Fusions of Cep85l and Ros1 have been observed in central nervous system tumors (PMID: 30171048) and with Pdgfrb in myeloproliferative neoplasms (PMID: 23186533).

RPS6KA5, ribosomal protein S6 kinase A5, is a mitogen and stress activated kinase (MSK) that phosphorylates a number of transcription factors including, CREB1 and ATF1, to promote cell proliferation and may regulate the immune system (PMID: 29327245). Overexpression of Rps6ka5 has been observed with increased survival in breast cancer patients (PMID: 29327245) and poor prognosis in colorectal cancer (PMID: 28314603) and glioma (PMID: 30020192).

TADA2A, transcriptional adaptor 2A, functions as part of the GCN5, PCAF, and STAGA histone acetyltransferase complexes, and is involved in regulation of beta-catenin signaling (PMID: 18059173). TADA2A fusions have been identified in breast carcinoma (PMID: 22101766) and in a colon cancer cell line (PMID: 29181107).

DDR1, discoidin domain receptor tyrosine kinase 1, encodes for a tyrosine kinase receptor that is activated by collagen and plays a necessary role in the development of mammary glands (PMID: 24671415). DDR1 overexpression and DDR1 mutations have been associated with a variety of cancers including lung (PMID: 31659178), leukemia (PMID: 21398698), melanoma (PMID: 31271515), ER-positive breast cancer (PMID: 30181556), and metastatic colon cancer (PMID: 32117772).

WNK1, WNK lysine deficient protein kinase 1, is a serine/threonine protein kinase involved in regulating ion transport and cellular processes, including immune function, proliferation, migration, and survival (PMID: 20094755, PMID: 21248166, PMID: 28178566). WNK1 mutations have been observed in breast, colon, lung, and brain cancers (PMID: 20094755), a fusion of WNK1 with ROS1 has been identified in non-small cell lung cancer (PMID: 30797499), and a WNK1-B4GALNT3 fusion has been identified in papillary thyroid carcinoma (PMID: 25803323).

CDK9, cyclin dependent kinase 9, interacts with cyclin-T1 (CCNT1) to form the positive transcription elongation factor B (P-TEFb) complex, which regulates transcription and mRNA processing (PMID: 28722178). Overexpression of Cdk9 in osteosarcoma correlates with poor prognosis (PMID: 30579871), may also play a role in mTOR driven acute myeloid leukemia (PMID: 30587525) and AKT2 driven cervical cancer (PMID: 30536701), and is overexpressed in chordoma (PMID: 31892980).

AGK, acylglycerol kinase, is a mitochondrial membrane lipid kinase (PMID: 25082432) that may play a role in regulating CD8 T-cell metabolic function through PTEN (PMID: 31204281). AGK fusions have been observed with BRAF in radiation-induced thyroid cancer and in melanoma (PMID: 24162670, PMID: 23890088, PMID: 30924609) and overexpression has been reported in renal cell carcinoma (PMID: 31900208).

MAST2, microtubule associated serine/threonine kinase 2, is a serine/threonine kinase that potentially functions as a scaffolding protein and interacts with syntrophin and utrophin (PMID: 18206861, PMID: 10404183). MAST2 fusions are recurrent in breast cancer (PMID: 22101766, PMID: 24140425) and overexpression has been associated with advanced liver cancer (PMID: 31882722).

ASPSCR1, ASPSCR1 tether for SLC2A4, UBX domain containing, encodes a protein involved in insulin-stimulated glucose transport (PMID: 25078495). Translocation t(X;17)(p11;q25) resulting in a fusion protein of ASPSCR1 and TFE3 is a defining characteristic of alveolar soft part sarcoma (PMID: 11438465, PMID: 30744536) and has also been observed in translocation renal cell carcinoma (PMID: 31400230, PMID: 30787990).

SCGB1C1, secretoglobin family 1C member 1, is a small secreted protein that synthesizes odor binding molecules and regulates cytokines in the nasal mucosa (PMID: 21385388, PMID: 29412801). Overexpression of SCGB1C1 has been observed in ovarian carcinoma (PMID: 23819652) and nasal polyps (PMID: 29412801).

SQSTM1, sequestosome 1, also referred to as p62, is a s a stress-inducible protein (PMID: 30499183) that partners with several other proteins to regulate cell growth and survival (PMID: 22841931, PMID: 22424619). SQSTM1 is overexpressed in several tumor types, including breast and prostate cancers (PMID: 26426686) and fusions with ALK (PMID: 21134980, PMID: 25413595), FGFR1 (PMID: 25501022), NTRK1 (PMID: 26565381), and NTRK2 (PMID: 28512244) have been observed.

CCR4, C-C motif chemokine receptor 4, is a transmembrane receptor that interacts with chemokines, and potentially plays a role in homeostasis and inflammatory response (PMID: 29099057, PMID: 25087232). Overexpression of CCR4 has been identified in mycosis fungoides (PMID: 29030090) and is associated with poor survival in hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 28959024).

LIFR, LIF receptor subunit alpha, is a receptor protein that forms complex with gp130 and transduces cell signaling, which plays a role in cell proliferation and differentiation (PMID: 24618404). Decreased expression of LIFR has been identified in pancreatic cancer (PMID: 27375070).

HES1, hes family bHLH transcription factor 1, is a transcriptional repressor of genes that require a bHLH protein for their transcription and is a downstream target of Notch signaling and plays a role in T-cell development (PMID: 27066918). Hes1 overexpression has been observed in a variety of solid tumor types (PMID: 25139105; PMID: 25234168; PMID: 24492635, PMID: 27066918).

ARMC10, armadillo repeat containting 10, directly decreases the transcriptional activity of Tp53 via binding to the DNA binding domain (PMID: 17904127) and mediates mitochondrial dynamics by serving as a substrate for AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) (PMID: 30631047). ARMC10 fusions with BRAF have been observed in lung cancer (PMID: 26314551) and melanoma (PMID: 30254212, PMID: 27864876).

COL14A1, collagen type XIV alpha 1 chain, encodes for a molecule associated with the extracellular matrix and plays a role in quiescence and cellular differentiation (PMID: 16129687). COL14A1 has been shown to form a fusion with FGFR2, which has been observed in cholangiocarcinoma (PMID: 24122810) and Col14a1 decreased expression has been observed in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 31598423).

SND1, staphylococcal nuclease and tudor domain containing 1, has several cellular functions including transcriptional co-activation and regulation of RNA splicing and editing (PMID: 24918049, PMID: 25405367). SND1 overexpression has been demonstrated in several tumor types, including colon, hepatocellular, and prostate cancers (PMID: 17909068, PMID: 19435788, PMID: 24918049).

CDK8, cyclin dependent kinase 8, encodes for a member of the mediator complex that binds cyclin-C (CCNC) to regulate gene expression through transcription (PMID: 24043446, PMID: 32071145, PMID: 31248103). Overexpression and/or amplification of CDK8 has been associated with colorectal cancer (PMID: 18794900), gastric cancer, breast cancer, melanoma (PMID: 32206448), and prostate cancer (PMID: 31382571).

PDGFRB, platelet derived growth factor receptor beta, is a receptor tyrosine kinase that plays a role in blood vessel development, cell proliferation, migration (PMID: 18483217, PMID: 20529858), and lymphangiogenesis (PMID: 31949689). PDGFRB fusions are associated with several tumor types (PMID: 24703957) and commonly found in myeloid neoplasms (PMID: 31999327, PMID: 31161074), while overexpression has been observed in metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (PMID: 31949689, PMID: 31308421) and somatic mutations in myofibroma (PMID: 31017643).

MSMB, microseminoprotein beta, is a protein secreted by the prostate that has putative tumor suppressor activity (PMID: 26939004, PMID: 28930560). A fusion of MSMB and NCOA4 has been detected in prostate cancer (PMID: 26939004), and MSMB overexpression has been demonstrated in ovarian cancer patients (PMID: 25188517), while decreased Msmb expression has been observed in prostate cancer (PMID: 29250809).

NUMBL, NUMB like, endocytic adaptor protein, is a homologue of Numb that is involved in various cellular processes including adhesion and ubiquitination, through regulation of Notch, Wnt, and Hedgehog signaling (PMID: 29507685, PMID: 27613838, PMID: 29507685). Downregulation of Numbl expression contributes to tumorigenicity and chemoresistance in tumor cells (PMID:  27613838, PMID: 31888545) and a fusion with ADCK4 has been observed in cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 30395845).

NRG4, neuregulin 4, is a ligand that binds Erbb4 (Her4),�potentially leading�to activation of downstream signaling (PMID: 10880430),�and acts as an endocrine signal that plays a role in lipid and glucose metabolism (PMID: 29106384, PMID: 25565202, PMID: 25401691). Decreased NRG4 expression has been observed In gastric cancer (PMID: 24728052) and in bladder cancer during progression (PMID: 15583696), increased expression of NRG4 has been�demonstrated in advanced prostate cancer�(PMID: 17545517), and a fusion of NRG4 with CCNY has�been identified in ovarian�clear cell carcinoma (PMID: 29633253).

CCNL1, cyclin L1, is involved in the regulation of pre-mRNA splicing and may be involved in transition of the cell-cycle from G0 to G1 (PMID: 15700036). Overexpression and/or amplification of Ccnl1 has been observed in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 16598186, PMID: 15700036) and altered expression has been observed in melanoma (PMID: 30987032).

FHL2, four and a half LIM domains 2, is an adaptor protein associated with transcriptional regulation of numerous cellular processes, including signal transduction, adhesion, proliferation, and apoptosis (PMID: 16389449, PMID: 18615633, PMID: 26211626). FHL2 overexpression has been observed in a variety of tumor types (PMID: 17352216), including glioblastoma (PMID: 29321665), colorectal (PMID: 26320172), and cervical cancers (PMID: 29800735), and a fusion of FHL2 and GLI2 has been identified in ovarian sclerosing stromal tumors (PMID: 31896750).

GCNT3, glucosaminyl (N-acetyl) transferase 3, mucin type, is a glycosyltransferase enzyme that produces mucin beta 6 N-acetylglucosaminides (PMID: 9915862, PMID: 28039261). Overexpression of Gcnt3 has been correlated with tumor-node-metastasis in NSCLC (PMID: 30355927) and with response to chemotherapy in colon and ovarian cancers (PMID: 29855486).

B4GALNT1, beta-1,4-N-acetyl-galactosaminyl transferase 1, is a glycosyltransferase essential for the synthesis of complex gangliosides, which are potential tumor-associated antigens (PMID: 27102283). Overexpression of B4galnt1 has been observed in clear cell renal cell carcinoma patients (PMID: 31491435) and overexpression of B4galnt1 in melanoma cells induces angiogenesis and cell growth (PMID: 31988291).

LOC389473, chromosome 5 open reading frame 13 pseudogene, is a pseudogene located 12kb upstream of the IGF2BP3 gene (PMID: 28193878). A LOC389473 fusion with THADA has been identified in thyroid cancer (PMID: 28193878).

TBP, TATA-box binding protein, is a transcription factor (PMID: 31917925) that functions as part of the DNA-binding protein complex (TFIID) to regulate RNA polymerase II transcription (PMID: 15970593) and interacts with MYC to regulate gene transcription (PMID: 31686052).

PROM1 (CD133), prominin 1, is a transmembrane glycoprotein that plays a role in retinal development, cell growth and is highly enriched on cancer stem cell membranes (PMID: 30399449, PMID: 20818439). Overexpression of Prom1 (Cd133) has been observed in a variety of tumor types, including, ovarian (PMID: 2916866), colorectal (PMID: 30061254), prostate (PMID: 29104488), rectal, lung, neuroblastoma (PMID: 29322842), and glioblastoma, where it may correlate with poor outcomes and resistance to chemotherapy and radiation therapy (PMID: 30399449), and PROM1 promoter hypermethylation has been observed in HNSCC (PMID: 32176088).

TRIM27, tripartite motif containing 27, is a member of the tripartite motif (TRIM) protein family (PMID: 29767249) and an E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase (PMID: 23419514) that regulates transcriptional repression, apoptosis, and the cell-cycle (PMID: 22829933). Fusions of TRIM27 with RET have been identified in salivary gland intraductal carcinoma (PMID: 30045065, PMID: 30610524) and papillary thyroid carcinoma (PMID: 12787916).

CEBPE, CCAAT enhancer binding protein epsilon, is a transcription factor that regulates gene expression in myeloid and lymphoid cells (PMID: 8661101). A CEBPE with fusion with IGH has been identified in B-lineage acute lymphoblastic leukemia (PMID: 19027493, PMID: 27019113) and altered expression has been observed in acute myeloid leukemia (PMID: 31164135).

PMS1, PMS1 homolog 1, mismatch repair system component, is a MutL homolog that interacts with MLH1 and has a putative role in DNA mismatch repair (PMID: 11920679). Germline PMS1 mutations are associated with Lynch syndrome (PMID: 19466295) and somatic mutations have been identified in multiple myeloma, colorectal cancer, and ovarian cancer (PMID: 30809292, PMID: 24614649, PMID: 24333356).

TFE3, transcription factor binding to IGHM enhancer 3, is a transcription factor that plays a role in developmental and cellular processes, including targeting genes downstream of TGF-beta signaling (PMID: 15118077). TFE3 fusions are commonly associated with renal cell carcinoma (PMID: 29713041, PMID: 30622287, PMID: 24455396), perivascular epithelioid cell tumors (PMID: 26975036, PMID: 31309284), alveolar soft-part sarcoma (PMID: 30347044), and epithelioid hemangioendothelioma (PMID: 32151991).

KLF5, Kruppel-like factor 5, is a transcription factor that activates or represses gene transcription, depending on cellular context, thereby, inhibiting or promoting cell survival (PMID: 24323942). Amplification and overexpression of Klf5 has been observed in a variety of tumor types, including intestinal, bladder, gastric, breast (PMID: 28963353), and pancreatic (PMID: 31327760).

FES, FES proto-oncogene, tyrosine kinase, plays a role in the maintenance of cellular transformation and demonstrates both oncogenic and tumor suppressive roles in cancer (PMID: 22202072). Decreased expression of Fes in melanoma has been commonly observed (PMID: 28463229) and inhibition of Fes may promote radiosensitivity (PMID: 31573955).

LRRFIP1, LRR binding FLII interacting protein 1, represses transcription of several genes and may play a role in cancer metastasis and invasion (PMID: 26047573). Expression of Lrrfip1 has been implicated in cellular invasion in colorectal cancer (PMID: 22750095) and a LRRFIP1-FGFR1 fusion has been observed in myeloproliferative syndrome (PMID: 19369959).

KDM3B, lysine demethylase 3B, is a histone demethylase influencing H3K9 histone modification and chromatin remodeling to regulate cell cycle progression and cell differentiation (PMID: 30514438). Decreased KDM3B expression has been reported in breast cancer (PMID: 23266085) and castration resistant prostate cancer (PMID: 31822799) and altered expression has been observed in leukemia (PMID: 28540746).

UBE2H, ubiquitin conjugating enzyme E2 H, catalyzes the association between ubiquitin and other proteins thus targets proteins for degradation (PMID: 8132613). A UBE2H fusion with MET has been identified in lung cancer (PMID: 30244854).

RASA3, RAS p21 protein activator 3, is a member of the GAP1 subfamily of GTPase-activating proteins that targets Ras and Rap (PMID: 25294679) and plays a role in inflammation and the immune system through regulation of pTh17 cells (PMID: 30446383). Hypomethylation and decreased expression of RASA3 has been reported in heptaocellular carcinoma (PMID: 29937930).

NISCH, nischarin, is a cytosolic protein with multiple binding partners, including integrin alpha-5, and is involved in regulation of cell signaling and migration (PMID: 26392073). NISCH may act as a tumor suppressor in breast cancer and ovarian cancer (PMID: 26392073, PMID: 21917605) and promoter hypermethylation has been observed in lung cancer (PMID: 31686733).

CDK12, cyclin dependent kinase 12, is a key regulator of transcription elongation, regulates the expression of genes involved in DNA repair, and is required for the maintenance of genomic stability (PMID: 24554720; PMID: 22012619). Loss and/or inactivation of CDK12 has been commonly observed in many solid tumor types, including prostate (PMID: 29906450, PMID: 31640893), breast, ovarian, endometrial, uterine (PMID: 30104286), and is a likely tumor suppressor (PMID: 30319007).

TMPRSS2, transmembrane protease,serine 2, is a member of the  type II transmembrane serine protease that is regulated by androgen (PMID: 26018085) and plays a role in viral spread, including coronaviruses (PMID: 30626688). TMPRSS2 fusions frequently occur with ETS transcription factors, including ERG and ETV1, and are commonly observed in prostate cancer (PMID: 20478527, PMID: 30680235, PMID: 31900904, PMID: 31915468).

KDM3A, lysine demethylase 3A, is a histone demethylase influencing histone modification and chromatin remodeling to regulate cell cycle progression, cell differentiation (PMID: 22581778), and mitochondrial biogenesis (PMID: 31629659). Increased expression of KDM3A has been reported in bladder cancer, lung cancer (PMID: 22020899, PMID: 18984585), pancreatic cancer (PMID: 31442435), and metastatic colon cancer (PMID: 30578902).

CCNK, cyclin K, interacts with CDK12 or CDK13 to regulate activity of RNA polymerase II mediated transcription (PMID: 30122539) and may also play a role in regulating the cell-cycle and DNA replication (PMID: 29760377). Overexpression of Ccnk has been shown to promote cell proliferation in cell culture (PMID: 20459741, PMID: 29760377, PMID: 28670704).

RNF11, ring finger protein 11, is a component of the ubiquitin-editing protein complex (PMID: 14755250) that may regulate Smurf2 and subsequent TGFbeta signalling (PMID: 28292929). A fusion of Rnf11 with Braf has been observed in histiocytic neoplasms (PMID: 26566875) and Rnf11 is overexpressed in several tumor types (PMID: 31985874).

FGF3, fibroblast growth factor 3, is an FGF family member involved in inner ear development and regulation of cell proliferation (PMID: 17601531, PMID: 16263090). Amplification of FGF3 is associated with several tumor types (PMID: 24265351, PMID: 12429977), including invasive breast carcinoma (PMID: 32152520) and esophageal cancer (PMID: 25214541).

VTCN1, V-set domain containing T cell activation inhibitor 1, is a member of the B7-family proteins that regulates immune response and tumor microenvironment (PMID: 28258701) and is an inhibitory immune checkpoint protein (PMID: 31555486, PMID: 31677920). VTCN1 overexpression has been identified in a wide variety of tumors (PMID: 28258701), including pancreatic cancer (PMID: 31282407), ovarian cancer (PMID: 31128028), and colorectal cancer (PMID: 30363700).

CCNE1, cyclin E1, predominately interacts with CKD2 to regulate the cell-cycle in transition from G1 to S phase (PMID: 14965268, PMID: 27461360). Amplification and/or overexpression of CCNE1 is common in chemoresistant ovarian high grade serous carcinomas (PMID: 27461360, PMID: 32044108), and in general, is associated with poor prognosis in solid tumor types (PMID: 30026836).

ATR, ATR serine/threonine kinase, is involved in regulation of the DNA damage response and mediation of cell-cycle checkpoints (PMID: 25512053). Inhibition of Atr selectively sensitizes cancerous cells to radiation and chemotherapy (PMID: 23583268, PMID: 31836456, PMID: 29054375).

PDE4D, phosphodiesterase 4D, is a cyclic nucleotide phosphodiesterase that regulates cAMP degradation (PMID: 16968949). Overexpression of PDE4D has been observed in a variety of cancers (PMID: 23536305),�including pancreatic ductal carcinoma (PMID: 31772658) and melanoma (PMID: 28092671),�decreased PDE4D expression has been demonstrated in bladder cancer (PMID: 30482227), and a fusion of PDE4D with CCNB1 has been identified in ovarian endometrioid�ovarian�carcinoma (PMID: 29633253).

CD276, CD276 molecule, is also known ad B7-H3 and is a member of the B7 family of immune checkpoint regulators (PMID: 30035102) and may be a co-inhibitory protein for T-cell activation by binding to the IL20RA receptor (PMID: 31308249). Overexpression of CD276 (B7-H3) has been observed to correlate with poor prognosis, cell migration, and cell invasion in many solid tumor types including, endometrial, cervical, breast, kidney, colorectal (PMID: 30035102), non-small cell lung cancer (PMID: 31737785), and meningioma (PMID: 31629137).

CCNT1, cyclin T1, interacts with CDK9 to form the positive transcription elongation factor B (P-TEFb) complex, which regulates transcription and mRNA processing (PMID: 28722178). Ccnt1 interacts with estrogen receptor alpha (PMID: 15940264) and is upregulated during activation and differentiation of lymphoid cells (PMID: 17352406).

CHEK1, checkpoint kinase 1, is a serine/threonine kinase activated in response to DNA damage that is responsible for mediating  checkpoint signaling from ATM and ATR (PMID: 23613359, PMID: 12781359). Overexpression of Chek1 has been observed in several tumor types, including gastric cancer, small cell lung cancer, T-cell leukemia (PMID: 25132270, PMID: 26867682, PMID: 28490518), and breast cancer (PMID: 31933717).

KPNA3, karyopherin subunit alpha 3, is a member of the importin alpha family and plays a role in importing cargo into the nucleus (PMID: 26245896). A TP53-KPNA3 fusion has been identified in osteosarcoma (PMID: 27626065) and overexpression has been reported in colorectal cancer (PMID: 30098595).

MELK, maternal embryonic leucine zipper kinase, is a serine/threonine-protein kinase that plays a role in regulation of the cell cycle, cell proliferation, and apoptosis (PMID: 30334367). Overexpression of Melk has been observed in a variety of tumor types, including cervical cancer (PMID: 30334367), hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 29151817), breast cancer (PMID: 27225691), melanoma (PMID: 29212029), leukemia (PMID: 25365263), endometrial carcinoma (PMID: 31915116), and intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (PMID: 31861475).

EPHA5, EPH receptor A5, is an ephrin receptor tyrosine kinase involved in cell adhesion, migration, and axon guidance (PMID: 19326470). Epha5 has been demonstrated to be overexpressed in lung cancer (PMID: 25623065) and esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 31956298), while decreased expression in ovarian cancer has been associated with poor patient outcomes (PMID: 27887627).

DTX3L, deltex E3 ubiquitin ligase 3L, is also known as B-lymphoma and BAL-associated protein (BBAP) and plays a role in histone modification and the DNA damage response through PARP1 activation (PMID: 23230272). DTX3L overexpression has been observed in melanoma (PMID: 26033450), in glioma patients with poor prognosis (PMID: 28627634), and may play a role in chemoresistance in hematological tumors (PMID: 28653881, PMID: 25605023).

KNSTRN, kinastrin, is a kinetochore-associated protein that regulates the cell cycle (PMID: 19667759) and chromosomal stability (PMID: 25194279), and plays a role in cellular apoptosis (PMID: 24718257). KNSTRN is broadly expressed  in various tissues and mutations have been observed in cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 25194279) and basal cell carcinoma (PMID: 26348826).

CCN2, cellular communication network factor 2, encodes for a matricellular protein that is induced by growth factors and plays a role in cell adhesion, aggregation, and migration in a number of cell types (PMID: 25120383, PMID: 15371538, PMID: 18789696). CCN2 overexpression has been associated with a poor prognosis in a variety of tumor types, including chondosarcoma, pancreatic cancer, esophageal cancer, and breast cancer (PMID: 30158025).

PDCD1LG2, programmed cell death 1 ligand 2, encodes PD-L2, a ligand for PD-1, which upon interaction exert an inhibitory effect on immune response (PMID: 11224527, PMID: 26432723, PMID: 28018338). PDCD1LG2 (PD-L2) is expressed in several tumor types, and amplification and overexpression of PD-L2, along with PD-L1, has been demonstrated in Hodgkin lymphoma and PMBCL (PMID: 28619999, PMID: 26432723).

YAP1, Yes1 associated transcriptional regulator, is a downstream transcriptional regulator in the Hippo signalling pathway, affecting organ size and tumor formation via cell proliferation and apoptotic control (PMID: 32128850). YAP amplification and/or overexpression has been reported in various cancers (PMID: 17974916, PMID: 22609812), including colon cancer (PMID: 31949692), esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 31949690, PMID: 31851786), gastric cancer (PMID: 31933860), and liver cancer (PMID: 31613226), and YAP1 fusions with multiple gene partners have been commonly observed (PMID: 31145701).

BRDT, bromodomain testis associated, encodes for a bromodomain containing protein, which plays a role in transcriptional regulation and spermatogenesis (PMID: 26565999) and functions to remodel hyperacetylated chromatin (PMID: 28580303). BRDT is defined as a cancer-testis antigen with increased gene expression in multiple cancer types (PMID: 10704737), including lung cancer (PMID: 26565999).

CCNI, cyclin I, interacts and activates Cdk5 (PMID: 26698249, PMID: 25500740) to regulate cell-cycle progression (PMID: 23907122) and may play a role in angiogenesis (PMID: 25667501). Increased expression of Ccni has been observed in ovarian cancer (PMID: 25667501) and has been implicated in cisplatin resistance  (PMID: 26698249).

KDM5C, llysine demethylase 5C, is a histone demethylase, regulating gene transcription through chromatin remodeling to regulate cell growth and differentiation (PMID: 25016185). KDM5C overexpression has been reported in prostate cancer (PMID: 25016185, PMID: 30921702) and mutations have been observed in clear cell renal cell carcinoma and pancreatic cancer (PMID: 31221981).

DHX15, DEAH-box helicase 15, encodes an RNA helicase, which plays a key role in mRNA splicing and ribosome biogenesis, and has been demonstrated to indirectly activate Nf-kappaB signaling in response to viral RNA (PMID: 25692149) and bind to Cmtr1 to inhibit methyltransferase activity (PMID: 30079402). DHX15 overexpression has been identified in acute myeloid leukemia (PMID: 29163777) and reduced DHX15 expression has been identified in glioma (PMID: 28829764).

ESRRA, estrogen related receptor alpha, encodes for a constitutively active transcription factor that is a member of the NR3B family, binding to coregulatory proteins and playing a role in energy metabolism (PMID: 18174917) and autophagy (PMID: 28841353). ESRRA overexpression has been associated with a worse prognosis in ovarian and breast cancer patients (PMID: 26542058) and the fusion, ESRRA-TEX40, has been identified in serous ovarian carcinoma (PMID: 21949640).

ICOSLG, inducible T cell costimulator ligand, encodes a member of the B7 family of ligands, which triggers T cell proliferation and cytokine production upon binding to the T cell receptor, ICOS (PMID: 11973139, PMID: 10549624). Expression of ICOSLG has been identified in myeloma and acute myeloid leukemia (PMID: 19188146, PMID: 16115907), and overexpression of ICOSLG has been observed in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 29147607).

ZKSCAN1, zinc finger with KRAB and SCAN domains 1, (also referred to as ZNF139), is a member of the zinc-finger family of transcription factors (PMID: 25561801, PMID: 26722429). Overexpression of ZKSCAN1 (PMID: 25561801) is associated with gastric cancer and ZKSCAN1 fusions have been identified in melanoma (PMID: 26013381, PMID: 26314551, PMID: 30254212).

YY1, YY1 transcription factor, is a zinc-finger transcription factor that regulates expression of genes involved in biological processes including cell growth, proliferation, and differentiation (PMID: 16611997, PMID: 20081375). Dysregulation of YY1 is associated with several tumor types including,  nasopharyngeal carcinoma (PMID: 30718276), YY1 mutations are recurrent in insulinoma (PMID: 20081375, PMID: 25787250) and a fusion with EWSR1 has been identified in mesothelioma (PMID: 23630070).

NEK11, NIMA-related kinase 11, is a member of the NEK protein kinase family�that negatively regulates�CDC25A (PMID: 19734889,�PMID: 20090422), and plays�a putative�role in cell cycle regulation in response to DNA damage (PMID: 23132929).�Decreased NEK11 expression has been observed in ovarian cancer (PMID: 24969318),�and NEK11 mutations have been associated with increased susceptibility to melanoma (PMID: 31704778).

RAD54B, RAD54 homolog B, is a member of the SWI2/SNF2 family of dsDNA-dependent ATPases, which plays a role in homologous recombination in DNA repair and in the DNA damage response (PMID: 11782437, PMID: 25384516). Overexpression of RAD54B has been demonstrated in several tumor types (PMID: 25384516), including lung adenocarcinoma (PMID: 31558081), liver cancer (PMID: 29956808), and breast cancer (PMID: 31612045).

KDM5B, lysine demethylase 5B, is a histone demethylase regulating gene transcription through H3K4 histone and chromatin modification to regulate cell growth and proliferation (PMID: 32155529, PMID: 30448242). Abnormal KDM5B expression has been reported in multiple cancer types including breast, prostate, bladder, and lung (PMID: 24937458) and overexpression has been associated with poor prognosis in laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma (PMID: 31934196) and hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 30344945).

KDELR2, KDEL endoplasmic reticulum protein retention receptor 2, is a KDEL (Lys-Asp-Glu-Leu) endoplasmic reticulum protein retention receptor that plays a role in the unfolded protein response (PMID: 30428351). A KDELR2 fusion with ROS1 has been identified in non-small cell lung cancer (PMID: 22980976) and Kdelr2 overexpression has been observed in glioblastoma (PMID: 31342232).

SPOP, speckle type BTB/POZ protein, is a substrate recognition subunit of the cullin-RING E3 ligase complex and regulates degradation of proteins involved in hormone signaling, epigenetic regulation, gene transcription, cell cycle, and metastasis, thus plays dual roles in carcinogenesis (PMID: 31495053, PMID: 31901237). SPOP mutations are frequently identified in prostate (PMID: 20668451) and endometrial cancer (PMID: 23104009), while overexpression of SPOP has been identified in renal cell carcinoma (PMID: 29801752).

WASF1, WASP family member 1, is part of the WAVE complex that regulates actin dynamic and membrane protrusion, thus contributing to cell migration (PMID: 25145849). Loss of WASF1 has been identified in prostate cancer (PMID: 25906751), overexpression of Wasf1 was observed in acute myeloblastic leukemia (PMID: 21281239), and fusion with BRAF has been identified in advanced solid tumors (PMID: 29320312).

PIM3, Pim-3 proto-oncogene, serine/threonine kinase, phosphorylates BAD to prevent apoptosis and promote cell survival and therefore, likely functions as an oncogene (PMID: 30370255). Overexpression of Pim3 has been reported in a variety of tumor types, including hepatoblastoma (PMID: 29854306), pancreatic (PMID: 26547690), prostate (PMID: 27826135), colorectal (PMID: 17270021), and gastric (PMID: 24488669).

STK32B, serine/threonine kinase 32B, is a protein kinase with uncharacterized biological function (PMID: 24885002). Decreased expression of Stk32b has been associated with aggressive clinicopathological features in oral squamous cell carcinoma and an STK32B fusion with ALK has been identified in leiomyosarcoma (PMID: 24885002, PMID: 30518629).

ETV6, ets variant 6, is a member of the ETS family of transcription factors, which functions as a transcriptional repressor and is involved in hematopoietic differentiation (PMID: 16828711). Fusions of ETV6 with various partners are frequently associated with hematological cancers (PMID: 22578774) and ETV6 mutations have been identified in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (PMID: 22162831) and acute myeloid leukemia (PMID: 18305557).

SSRP1, structure specific recognition protein 1, is a histone chaperone and forms part of the facilitates chromatin transcription (FACT) complex to mediate DNA replication, DNA damage repair, apoptosis and cell cycle regulation (PMID: 29048646, PMID: 32165637). SSRP1 overexpression has been observed in glioma, where it may correlate with stage (PMID:  29048646), and in breast cancer (PMID: 28496363) and hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 26755331).

RAD51C, RAD51 paralog C, functions in homologous recombination in DNA repair and plays a role in cell cycle checkpoint signaling in response to DNA damage (PMID: 21821141). Germline mutations in RAD51C are associated with increased susceptibility to breast and ovarian cancers (PMID: 21821141, PMID: 31446535) and overexpression of RAD51C has been observed in ovarian cancer (PMID: 32055267).

CASP7, caspase 7, apoptosis-related cysteine peptidase, plays a central role in the execution-phase of cell apoptosis (PMID: 23979156). Germline variants in Casp7 have been observed to modify risk in cervical cancer (PMID: 25784056), gastric adenocarcinoma (PMID: 24040159), and childhood leukemia (PMID: 22548721).

CCNT2, cyclin T2, interacts with CDK9 to form the positive transcription elongation factor B (P-TEFb) complex, which regulates transcription and mRNA processing (PMID: 15563843, PMID: 9499409). Overexpression of Ccnt2 may play a role in gastric cancer (PMID: 29849811) and expression may be regulated by microRNA 192 (miR-192) in acute myeloid leukemia (PMID: 28409330) and miRNA-188-5p in osteosarcoma (PMID: 31957815).

IFIT1, interferon induced protein with tetratricopeptide repeats 1, is a member of the IRF-inducible gene family that plays a role in the immune defense against RNA viruses and may regulate expression of inflammatory cytokines (PMID: 30282041, PMID: 31921891). Overexpression of Ifit1 in glioblastoma has been associated with improved prognosis and increased survival (PMID: 26980050), while overexpression in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma is associated with poor prognosis (PMID: 31977029).

CIC, capicua transcriptional repressor, is a member of the HMG-box superfamily of transcriptional repressors that regulates gene activation downstream of EGFR/Ras/ERK signaling (PMID: 32029440, PMID: 30737375, PMID: 29578365). CIC mutations have been observed in oligodendroglioma (PMID: 21817013; PMID: 22588899), multiple myeloma (PMID: 32043788), and fusions are associated with sarcoma (PMID: 16717057, PMID: 31870501), while decreased expression has been reported in glioblastoma (PMID: 30737375).

CLIP2, CAP-GLY domain containing linker protein 2, links membranes to microtubules and cell organelles and plays a role in cell polarity (PMID: 21273437). Overexpression of Clip2 has been observed as a radiation exposure marker in papillary thyroid carcinoma (PMID: 25957251, PMID: 25284583) and a fusion protein with Braf has been identified in non-Langerhans histiocytic neoplasms (PMID: 26566875) and with RET in pediatric spindle mesenchymal tumors (PMID: 31994201).

USH2A, usherin, encodes a basement membrane protein whose function is unclear but appears to be important in cochlear and retinal development (PMID: 11788194). Germline mutations in USH2A are commonly reported in Usher syndrome (PMID: 32093671) and in non-syndromic retinitis pigmentosa (PMID: 31904091) and mutations in various cancers have also been reported (PMID: 11788194, Cancer Res April 15, 2012 72; 3959).

CCT2, chaperonin containing TCP1 subunit 2, is a component the molecular chaperone T-complex protein 1 Ring complex (TRiC), which functions in telomere maintenance (PMID: 25467444, PMID: 25704758). Overexpression of Cct2 has been observed in small cell lung cancer (PMID: 29299146) and in extracellular vesicles in glioblastoma (PMID: 30451371).

TBX3, T-box transcription factor 3, is a member of the T-box transcription factor family that functions in embryogenesis, cell cycle control, and cellular senescence (PMID: 22002537, PMID: 31669645). Overexpression of Tbx3 has been identified in cancers including breast, pancreatic, liver (PMID: 30578408), bladder, melanoma (PMID: 24025717), rhabdomyosarcoma (PMID: 32098189), and hypopharyngeal carcinoma (PMID: 31897121).

SETDB1, SET domain bifurcated histone lysine methyltransferase 1, is a histone methyltransferase that regulates chromatin structure through methylation of H3K9 to repress gene transcription (PMID: 27732843, PMID: 28887438), and has a role in maintaining stem cell pluripotency (PMID: 19884255). Amplification of SETDB1 has been observed in a variety of cancers (PMID: 27732843), including lung (PMID: 23770855), breast (PMID: 25537518), and melanoma (PMID: 31131878).

TRAF7, TNF receptor-associated factor 7, E3 ubiquitin protein ligase, acts as an E3 ligase for multiple NF-kappaB pathway members and for Tp53, and plays a role in regulation of several signaling pathways and in promoting apoptosis (PMID: 23128672, PMID: 22105767, PMID: 27808423). Mutations in TRAF7 are associated with non-NF2 meningiomas (PMID: 23348505, PMID: 31963394, PMID: 31177425, PMID: 30294322) and papillary mesothelioma (PMID: 30171198), while overexpression has been observed in hepatocellular carcinoma (PMID: 31730901).

CDK14, cyclin dependent kinase 14, is regulated by cyclin-Y (CCNY) (PMID: 19524571) and plays a role in the transition of the cell-cycle through the Wnt signaling pathway (PMID: 29557391).
